explanations: The French "pendant le jour" (during the day), in the context of continuing conversations previously held in the evening, implies the daytime of the following day. The translation "next day" makes this temporal sequence explicit, clarifying that the Marquise wished to continue the discussions on the day immediately after their prior evening meeting.

The French "à poursuivre nos Entretiens" translates to "to continue our conversations." The English translation "to go on where I left off" makes explicit the *manner* of this continuation, specifying that it would be a direct resumption from the point at which the previous discussion had concluded, a detail only implied in the French.

The French phrase "nous ne devions confier nos chimeres qu'à la Lune & aux Etoiles" means "we should confide our chimeras only to the Moon and Stars." The restrictive "ne...que..." construction implies an exclusion of others. The English translation "we would trust our Chymaeras with no body else" makes this implied exclusion explicit by directly stating the negative consequence (not confiding in others).

The French clause "puis qu'aussi-bien elles en étoient l'objet." (since, indeed, they were the object/subject of them) is translated with several explicitations in "since the Moon and Stars were become the Subject of our Discourse". Specifically: 1) The pronoun "elles" (they) is explicitly identified as "the Moon and Stars." 2) The verb "étoient" (were - imperfect tense suggesting a state) is rendered as "were become," which emphasizes a transition to or establishment of that state. 3) The general term "l'objet" (the object/subject) is specified as "the Subject." 4) The pronoun "en" (of them/it) is expanded to the clearer phrase "of our Discourse," making the reference explicit.

The French "Nous ne manquasmes pas à aller le soir" literally means "We did not fail to go in the evening." The English translation "At Night we went again" adds the word "again," thereby making explicit the repetitive nature of their evening visits to the park for these conversations. This recurrence was implied by the ongoing nature of their discussions but is overtly stated in the translation.

chunks.source_manual: <P040>J'ai bien des nouvelles à vous apprendre, luy dis-je, la Lune que je vous disois hier qui selon toutes les apparences estoit habitée, pourroit bien ne l'être point; j'ay pensé à une chose qui met ses Habitants en peril. Je ne soufriray point cela, répondit-elle. Hier vous m'aviez preparée à voir ces Gens là venir icy au premier jour, & aujourd'huy ils ne seroient seulement pas au monde? Vous ne vous joüerez point ainsi de moy, vous m'avez fait croire les Habitans de la Lune; j'ay surmonté la peine que j'y avois, je les croiray. Vous allez bien vîte, repris-je, il faut ne donner que la moitié de son esprit aux choses de cette espece que l'on croit, & en reserver une autre moitié libre, où le contraire puisse estre admis, s'il en est besoin. Je ne me paye point de Sentences, répliqua-t-elle, allons au fait. Ne faut-il pas raisonner de la Lune comme de <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE>? Non, répondis-je, la Lune ne ressemble pas autant à la Terre que <NCE>Saint Denis ressemble à Paris</NCE>. Le Soleil éleve de la Terre & des Eaux, des exhalaisons & des vapeurs, qui montant en l'air jusqu'à quelque hauteur, s'y assemblent, & forment les nüages. Ces nüages suspendus voltigent irregulierement autour de nostre Globe, & ombragent tantost un Païs, tantost un autre. <UP></UP> Qui verroit la Terre de loin, remarqueroit souvent quelques changemens sur sa surface, parce qu'un grand Païs couvert par des nüages, seroit un endroit obscur, & deviendrait plus lumineux dés qu'il serait découvert. On verroit des taches qui changeroient de place, ou s'assembleroient diversement, ou disparoîtroient tout à fait. On verroit donc aussi ces mesmes changemens sur la face de la Lune, <UP></UP> si elle avoit des nüages autour d'elle; mais tout au contraire, toutes ses taches sont fixes, ses endroits lumineux le sont toûjours, & voila le malheur. A ce compte-là, le Soleil n'éleve point de vapeurs ny d'exhalaisons de dessus la Lune. C'est donc <UP></UP> un Corps infiniment plus dur & plus solide que nostre Terre, dont les parties les plus subtiles se dégagent aisément d'avec les autres, & montent en haut dés qu'elles sont mises en mouvement par la chaleur. Il faut que ce soit quelque amas de Rochers & de Marbres, où il ne se fait point d'évaporations; d'ailleurs elles se font si naturellement & si necessairement ou il y a des Eaux, qu'il ne doit point y avoir d'eaux ou il ne s'en fait point. Qui sont donc les Habitans de ces Rochers qui ne peuvent rien produire, & de ce Païs qui n'a point d'eaux? Et quoy, s'écria-t-elle, il ne vous souvient plus que vous m'avez assurée qu'il y avoit dans la Lune des Mers que l'on distinguoit d'icy? <UP></UP> Ce n'est qu'une conjecture, répondis-je, j'en suis bien fâché; ces endroits obscurs qu'on prend pour des Mers, ne sont peut-estre que <IIM>de grandes cavitez</IIM>. De la distance ou nous sommes, il est permis de ne pas deviner tout à fait juste. Mais, dit-elle, cela suffira-t-il pour nous faire abandonner les Habitans de la Lune? Non pas tout à fait, Madame, répondis-je, nous ne nous déterminerons ni pour eux, ny contre eux. Je vous avouë ma faiblesse <NCP></NCP>, repliqua-t-elle, je ne suis point capable d'une si parfaite indétermination, j'ay besoin de croire. Fixez-moy promptement à une opinion sur les Habitans de la Lune, conservons les, ou aneantissons les pour jamais & qu'il n'en soit plus parlé; mais conservons les plûtost, s'il se peut, j'ay pris pour eux une inclination que j'aurois de la peine à perdre. Je ne laisseray donc pas la Lune deserte, repris-je, repeuplons là pour vous faire plaisir. A la verité, puisque l'apparence des taches de la Lune ne change point, on ne peut pas croire qu'elle ait des nüages autour d'elle, qui ombragent tantost une partie, tantost une autre; mais ce n'est pas à dire qu'elle ne pousse point hors d'elle de vapeurs ny d'exhalaisons. Nos nüages que nous voïons portez en l'air ne sont que des exhalaisons & des vapeurs, qui au sortir de la Terre estoient separées en trop petites parties pour pouvoir estre veuës, & qui ont rencontré un peu plus haut une froideur qui les a reserrées, & renduës visibles par la reünion de leurs parties, aprés quoy ce sont de gros nüages qui flotent en l'air ou ils sont des Corps étrangers, jusqu'à ce qu'ils retombét en pluyes. Mais ces mesmes vapeurs, & ces mesmes exhalaisons se tiennent quelquefois assez dispersées pour estre imperceptibles, & ne se ramassent qu'en formant <IIM>des rosées tres subtiles</IIM>, qu'on ne voit tomber d'aucune nuée. Il se peut aussi que les vapeurs qui sortent de la Lune, (car enfin il faut qu'il en sorte, il n'est pas croyable que la Lune soit une masse dont toutes les parties soient d'une égale solidité; toutes également en repos les unes auprés des autres, toutes incapables de recevoir aucun changement par l'action du Soleil sur elles; nous ne connoissons aucun Corps de cette nature, les Marbres mesmes n'en sont pas, tout ce qui est le plus solide change & s'altere, ou par le mouvement secret & invisible qu'il a en luy-mesme, ou par celuy qu'il reçoit de dehors.) Il se peut donc que les vapeurs qui sortent de la Lune, ne se rassemblent point autour d'elle en nuages, & ne retomberont point sur elle en pluyes, mais seulement en rosées. Il suffit pour cela que l'air dont apparemment la Lune est environnée en son particulier, comme nostre Terre l'est du sien, soit un peu different de nostre Air, & les vapeurs de la Lune un peu differentes des vapeurs de la Terre, ce qui est quelque chose de plus que vraysemblable. Sur ce pied-là, il faudra que la matiere étant disposée dans la Lune autrement que sur la Terre, les effets soient diferens, mais il n'importe; du moment que nous avons trouvé un mouvement interieur dans les parties de la Lune, ou produit par des causes étrangeres, voila ses Habitans qui renaissent, & nous avons le fond necessaire pour leur subsistance. Cela nous fournira des fruits, des bleds, des eaux, & tout ce que nous voudrons. J'entends des fruits, des bleds, des eaux à la maniere de la Lune que je fais profession de ne pas connoistre, le tout proportionné aux besoins de ses Habitans que je ne connais pas non plus.</P040> <P041>C'est-à-dire, me dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que vous sçavez seulement que tout est bien, sans sçavoir comment il est; c'est beaucoup d'ignorance <UP></UP> sur bien peu de science, mais il faut s'en consoler; je suis encore trop heureuse que vous ayez rendu à la Lune ses Habitans. Je suis mesme fort contente que vous luy donniez un Air qui l'envelope en son particulier, il me sembleroit desormais que sans cela une Planete seroit trop nuë.</P041>
chunks.target_manual: <P031>Well, Madam, said I, I have great News for you; that which I told you last Night, of the Moon's being inhabited, may not be so now: There is a new Fancy got into my Head, which puts those People in great Danger. I cannot suffer it, said she; yesterday you were preparing me to receive a Visit from 'em, and now there are no such People in Nature: Once you would have me believe the Moon was inhabited; I surmounted the Difficulty I had, and will now believe it. You are a little too nimble, I reply'd; did I not advise you never to be entirely convinc'd in things of this nature, but to reserve half of your understanding free and disengag'd, that you may admit of the contrary opinion, if there be any occasion. I care not for your Sentences, said she, let us come to matter of Fact. Are we not to consider the Moon as <NCE>Greenwhich</NCE>? No, said I, the Moon doth not so much resemble the Earth, as <NCE>Greenwich doth London</NCE>: The Sun draws from the Earth and Water, Exhalations and Vapours, which mounting to a certain height in the Air, do there assemble, and form the Clouds; these uncertain Clouds are driven irregularly round the Globe, sometimes shadowing one Countrey, and sometimes another; he then who beholds the Earth from a-far off, will see frequent alterations upon its surface, because a great Country overcast with Clouds, will appear dark or light, as the Clouds stay, or pass over it; he will see the Spots on the Earth often change their Place, and appear, or disappear as the Clouds remove; but we see none of these changes wrought upon the Moon, which would certainly be the same, were there but Clouds about her; but on the contrary, all her Spots are fix'd and certain, and her light parts continue where they were at first, which truly is a great misfortune; for by this reason, the Sun draws no Exhalations or Vapours above the Moon; so that it appears she is a Body infinitely more hard, and solid than the Earth, whose subtile parts are easily separated from the rest, and mount upwards as soon as Heat puts them in Motion: But it must be a heap of Rock and Marble, where there is no Evaporation; besides, Exhalations are so natural and necessary where there is Water, that there can be no Water at all, where there is no Exhalation; and what sort of Inhabitants must those be, whose Countrey affords no Water, is all Rock, and produceth nothing? Very fine, said she, you have forgot since, you assur'd me, we might from hence distinguish Seas in the Moon; nay, <UP>You or your Friends were Godfathers to some of 'em. Pray, what is become of your Caspian Sea, and your Black Lake? All Conjecture, Madam, I reply'd, tho' for your Ladyships sake, I am very sorry for it;</UP> for those dark places we took to be Seas, may perhaps be nothing but large Cavities; 'tis hard to guess aright at so great a distance. But will this suffice then, said she, to extirpate the People in the Moon? Not altogether, I reply'd, we will neither determine for, nor against them. I must own my weakness <NCP>(if it be one)</NCP> said she, I cannot be so perfectly undetermin'd as you would have me to be, but must believe one way, or the other; therefore pray fix me quickly in my opinion; as to the Inhabitants of the Moon; preserve or annihilate them, as you shall think fit; and yet methinks I have a strange inclination for 'em, and would not have 'em destroy'd, if it were possible to save 'em. You know, Madam, said I, I can deny you nothing; the Moon shall be no longer a Defart, but to do you service, we will repeople her. Since to all appearance, the Spots in the Moon do not change, I cannot conceive there are any Clouds about her, that sometimes obscure one part, and sometimes another; yet this doth not hinder, but that the Moon sends forth Exhalations, and Vapours. Our Clouds which we see in the Air, are nothing but Exhalations and Vapours, which at their coming out of the Earth, were separated into such minute Particles, that they could not be discern'd; but as they ascend higher, they are condens'd by the Cold, and by the re- union of their Parts, are render'd visible; after which they become great Clouds, which fluctuate in the Air, till they return back again in Rain; however these Exhalations and Vapours do sometimes keep themselves so dispers'd, that they are imperceptible; or if they do assemble, it is in forming such subtile Dews, that they cannot be discern'd to fall from any Cloud. It may likewise happen, that the Vapours which go out of the Moon (for it is incredible that the Moon is such a Mass, that all its Parts are of an equal Solidity, all at rest one with another, and all incapable of any alteration from the efficacy of the Sun; I am sure we are yet unacquainted with such a Body: Marble it self is of another Nature, and even that which is most Solid, is subject to Change and Alteration; either from the secret and invisible motion it hath within it self, or from that which it receives from without) it may so happen then, that the Vapours which issue from the Moon, may not assemble round her in Clouds, and may not fall back again in Rain, but only in Dews. It is sufficient for this, that the Air with which the Moon is environ'd, <NCP>(for it is certain that the Moon is encompassed with Air as well as the Earth)</NCP> be a little different from our Air, and the Vapours of the Moon a little different from those of the Earth, which is very probable. Hereupon the matter being otherwise dispos'd in the Moon than on the Earth, the Effects must be different; tho' it is of no great consequence whether they are or no; for from the moment we have found an inward motion in the parts of the Moon, or produced by foreign Causes, here is enough for the new birth of its Inhabitants, and a sufficient and necessary fund for their Subsistence. This will furnish us with Corn, Fruit, Water, according to the custom or manner of the Moon, which I do not pretend to know; and all proportion'd to the wants and use of the Inhabitants, with whom I pretend to be as little acquainted. That is to say, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you know all is very well, without knowing how it is so, which is a great deal of Ignorance <UP>upon a very little Knowledge;</UP> however I comfort my self, that you have given the Moon her Inhabitants again, and have wrap'd her in an Air of her own, without which a Planet would seem but very naked.</P031>

explanations: The French "il faut ne donner..." (one must only give...) is a general, impersonal recommendation. The English "did I not advise you..." recasts this as a reminder of specific, prior advice personally given by the speaker to the Marquise, thereby making explicit a presumed history of their conversation or a more personal directive that was only implied by the impersonal "il faut" structure.

The French "Ces nüages suspendus" (These suspended clouds) describes the clouds physically. The English "these uncertain Clouds" introduces the adjective "uncertain," explicitly adding a qualitative judgment about their nature that is not directly stated in the source phrase, thus adding a layer of interpretation.

The French "disparoîtroient tout à fait" (would disappear completely) states the effect. The English "disappear as the Clouds remove" explicitly adds the cause by specifying "as the Clouds remove," spelling out the causal relationship (the clouds' action leading to disappearance) which was left unstated in the original phrase.

The French "ses endroits lumineux le sont toûjours" (its luminous places are always so) is concise. The English "her light parts continue where they were at first" expands on "toûjours" (always) by adding "where they were at first," which clarifies the nature of this "always" by specifying continuity from an initial state/observation, making the meaning more explicit.

The French "A ce compte-là" (by that reckoning/on that account) implies a logical sequence. The English "for by this reason" makes this logical connection more explicit by using the phrase "by this reason," directly spelling out the inferential link that was only implied by the French idiom.

The French "C'est donc" (It is therefore) introduces a direct conclusion. The English "so that it appears" translates "donc" (therefore) with "so that," explicitly marking the statement as a consequence, and adds "it appears," which further clarifies the inferential nature of the statement that was more assertively presented in the source.

The French describes inhabitants "de ces Rochers qui ne peuvent rien produire, & de ce Païs qui n'a point d'eaux" (of these Rocks that can produce nothing, & of this Country that has no water). The English "whose Countrey affords no Water, is all Rock, and produceth nothing" explicitly consolidates the description of the environment by stating the "Countrey... is all Rock," directly linking the previously mentioned "Rochers" (Rocks) to the overall nature of the land and making this characteristic an explicit attribute of the "Countrey."

The French "des Mers que l'on distinguoit d'icy?" (Seas that one distinguished from here?) refers generally to observed lunar seas. The English translation massively expands this by adding: "nay, You or your Friends were Godfathers to some of 'em. Pray, what is become of your Caspian Sea, and your Black Lake?". This addition provides specific, culturally relevant details about the contemporary practice of naming lunar features and gives concrete examples, thereby explicating the kind of general scientific activity and knowledge Fontenelle's work alluded to, effectively re-writing the line to include far more explicit information.

The French "j'en suis bien fâché" (I am very sorry about it) is a general expression of regret. The English "tho' for your Ladyships sake, I am very sorry for it" adds the specific motivation "for your Ladyships sake." This addition makes explicit the philosopher's personal consideration for the Marquise's feelings as the reason for his sorrow, a social nuance only implied in the original.

The French "ma faiblesse" (my weakness) is a straightforward admission. The English translation adds the parenthetical qualifier "(if it be one)" immediately after "my weakness." This phrase adds a layer of self-reflection or rhetorical hedging by the Marquise that is not present in the source, making an internal thought or social posture explicit.

The French "j'ay besoin de croire" (I need to believe) is a concise statement of need. The English "but must believe one way, or the other" expands this by explicitly detailing the nature of the belief required in this specific conversational context (i.e., choosing between the two stated options about lunar inhabitants), thereby clarifying an implication that was less spelled out in the French.

The French "conservons les, ou aneantissons les pour jamais" (let's preserve them, or let's annihilate them for ever) suggests a joint action or proposal. The English "preserve or annihilate them, as you shall think fit" shifts the agency by adding "as you shall think fit." This phrase explicitly assigns the discretion and authority for this decision to the philosopher, spelling out a deference to his judgment that was not directly stated in the French appeal.

The French "pour vous faire plaisir." (to please you.) succinctly states the philosopher's motive. The English translation adds the entirely new preceding clause "You know, Madam, said I, I can deny you nothing;". This addition explicitly articulates the philosopher's gallant deference to the Marquise, making overt a sentiment that was only briefly implied by the simpler French phrase, adding significant relational context.

The French "ne se ramassent qu'en formant des rosées tres subtiles" (only gather/assemble by forming very subtle dews) describes a direct process. The English "or if they do assemble, it is in forming such subtile Dews" introduces "if they do assemble" as an explicit conditional step or alternative to remaining dispersed, before stating the outcome ("it is in forming"). This spells out the logical structure of the process more explicitly than the condensed French.

The French "les Marbres mesmes n'en sont pas" (even marbles are not [like that/of that kind]) is a concise negation of similarity. The English "Marble it self is of another Nature" explicates *how* marbles are different by stating they are "of another Nature." This addition clarifies the implied contrast by providing a more descriptive reason for the dissimilarity.

The French "apparemment" (apparently) indicates the Moon's atmosphere is a supposition. The English translation omits a direct translation of "apparemment" and instead inserts the parenthetical assertion "(for it is certain that the Moon is encompassed with Air as well as the Earth)". This transforms a nuanced likelihood into a definite statement, explicitly adding a justification and asserting as fact an idea that was presented more tentatively in the source.

The French "mais il n'importe" (but it doesn't matter/it's not important) is a brief dismissal. The English "tho' it is of no great consequence whether they are or no" expands this by explicitly clarifying *what* is of no consequence – "whether they [the effects mentioned previously] are [different] or no." This spells out the referent of "il" (it) and the scope of "n'importe," which were only anaphorically implied in the French.

chunks.source_manual: <P042>Ces deux Airs diferens, repris-je, contribuent à empescher la communication des deux Planetes. S'il ne tenoit qu'à voler; que sçavons-nous, comme je vous disois hier, si on ne volera pas fort bien quelque jour? J'avoüe pourtant qu'il n'y a pas beaucoup d'apparence. Le grand éloignement de la Lune à la Terre seroit encore une difficulté à surmonter, qui est assurement considerable, mais quand mesme elle ne s'y rencontreroit pas, quand mesme les deux Planetes seroient proches, <UP></UP> il ne seroit pas possible de passer de l'Air de l'une dans l'air de l'autre. L'eau est l'air des Poissons, ils ne passent jamais dans l'Air des Oyseaux, ny les Oyseaux dans l'air des Poissons; ce n'est pas la distance qui les en empesche, c'est que chacun a pour prison l'air qu'il respire. Nous trouvons que le nostre est mêlé de vapeurs plus épaisses & plus grossieres que celuy de la Lune. A ce compte, un Habitan de la Lune qui seroit arrivé aux confins de nostre Monde, se noyeroit dés qu'il entreroit dans nostre Air, & nous le verrions tomber mort sur la Terre.</P042>
chunks.target_manual: <P032>'Tis these two different Airs, said I, that hinder the Communication of the two Planets; if it was only flying, as I told you yesterday, who knows but we may improve it to perfection, tho' I confess there is but little hopes of it; the great distance between the Moon and the Earth is a difficulty not easily to be surmounted, yet were the distance but inconsiderable, and the <UP>two Planets almost contiguous</UP>, it would be still impossible to pass from the Air of the one, into the Air of the other: The Water is the Air of Fishes, they never pass into the Air of the Birds, nor the Birds into the Air of the Fish; and yet 'tis not the distance that hinders them, but both are emprison'd by the Air they breath in; we find our Air consists of thicker and grosser Vapours than the Air of the Moon. So that one of her Inhabitants arriving at the Confines of our World, as soon as he enters our Air will inevitably drown himself, and we shall see him fall dead on the Earth.</P032>

not easily to be surmounted

explanations: The French "si on ne volera pas fort bien quelque jour?" (if one will not fly very well some day?) describes achieving a good state of flying. The English translation "who knows but we may improve it to perfection," makes this more explicit by (1) specifying the object of improvement as "it" (flying), (2) introducing the concept of a process with "improve," and (3) elevating the standard from "very well" (fort bien) to "perfection." This expansion clarifies the potential development of flight to a higher, more refined state.

The French phrase "qui est assurement considerable" (which is certainly considerable) describes an inherent quality of the difficulty. The English translation "not easily to be surmounted" makes explicit the practical consequence of this considerable difficulty—that it would be hard to overcome—thereby spelling out an implication that was only suggested in the original.

The French "proches" (close, near) is rendered as "almost contiguous." The term "contiguous" implies direct contact or sharing a border. By using "almost contiguous," the translator makes the degree of closeness more specific and extreme, adding clarifying information to the hypothetical scenario by defining a more precise spatial relationship than the general term "proches."

The French word "chacun" (each one, everyone) is translated as "both." In the context where fish and birds have just been mentioned as distinct groups, "both" explicitly limits the reference of "chacun" to these two specific groups, thereby spelling out a connection that was previously only implied by proximity.

The French anaphoric pronoun "le nostre" (ours), refers to "nostre Air" (our air) mentioned in the preceding sentence. The English translation "our Air" makes the referent "Air" explicit, adding clarifying information by fully specifying what "ours" refers to, which was only pronominally implied in the source text.

The French "se noyeroit" (would drown) expresses a conditional consequence. The English translation "will inevitably drown himself" adds the adverb "inevitably." This addition makes explicit the certainty and unpreventable nature of the drowning, a nuance strongly implied by the context and the directness of the French conditional but not overtly stated.

chunks.source_manual: <P043>Oh, que j'aurois d'envie, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <UP></UP> qu'il arrivast quelque grand naufrage <UP></UP> qui répandist icy bon nombre de ces Gens-là, dont nous irions considerer à nostre aise les figures extraordinaires! Mais,repliquay-je, s'ils estoient assez habiles pour naviger sur la surface exterieure de nostre Air, & que de là par la curiosité de nous voir, ils nous peschassent comme des Poissons, cela vous plairoit-il? Pourquoy non, répondit-elle en riant? Pour moy, je me mettrois de mon propre mouvement dans leurs Filets, seulement pour avoir le plaisir de voir ceux qui m'auroient peschée.</P043>
chunks.target_manual: <P033>I should rejoyce at a Wreck, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, <UP>as much as my Neighbours on the Coast of Sussex</UP>; how pleasant would it be to see 'em lie scatter'd on the ground, where we might consider at our ease, their extraordinary Figures? But what, said I, if they could swim on the outward surface of our Air, and be as curious to see us, as you are to see them; should they Angle or cast a Net for us, as for so many Fish, would that please you? why not? said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>; For my part I would go into their Nets of mine own accord, were it but for the pleasure to see such strange Fishermen.</P033>
source_segments: Oh, que j'aurois d'envie, s'écria la Marquise, qu'il arrivast quelque grand naufrage
target_segments: I should rejoyce at a Wreck, said the Countess, as much as my Neighbours on the Coast of Sussex
lie scatter'd on the ground
Angle or cast a Net

explanations: The translator adds the comparative phrase 'as much as my Neighbours on the Coast of Sussex' to the Countess's expression of joy. This addition is not present in the source text. It makes the nature of her rejoicing explicit by likening it to the notorious practice of 'wrecking' (luring ships to shore or plundering shipwrecks) known on the Sussex coast, thereby clarifying the intensity and potentially morally dubious, opportunistic quality of her wish, which was only implied by the French 'Oh, que j'aurois d'envie' (Oh, how I would long/wish).

The French 'répandist icy' (spread/scattered here) describes the result of the shipwreck in a general way. The English translation 'lie scatter'd on the ground' makes the aliens' physical state and location more explicit and vivid, adding the detail of them 'lying on the ground,' which is only implicitly suggested by the French verb and the context of a shipwreck.

The French verb 'peschassent' (fished) is a general term for the act of fishing. The English translation 'Angle or cast a Net' explicitates this action by providing specific methods of fishing (angling, using a net), thereby expanding a general term into concrete examples of how the aliens might 'fish' for humans.

The French phrase 'ceux qui m'auroient peschée' literally means 'those who would have fished me,' referring factually to the identity of the fishers. The English translation 'such strange Fishermen' adds the explicit adjective 'strange.' While the context (aliens from another world) implies their strangeness, the source phrase itself does not explicitly characterize them as such. This addition clarifies the perceived nature of these hypothetical fishermen.

chunks.source_manual: <P044>Songez, repliquay-je, que vous n'arriveriez que bien malade au haut de nostre Air, il n'est pas respirable pour nous dans toute son étenduë, il s'en faut bien, il ne l'est déjà presque plus au haut de certaines <UP></UP> Montagnes, & je m'étonne bien que ceux qui ont la folie de croire que des Genies corporels habitent l'air le plus pur, ne disent aussi que ce qui fait que ces Genies ne nous rendent que des visites & tres-rares & tres-courtes, c'est qu'il y en a peu d'entre eux qui sçachent plonger, & que ceux-la mesme ne peuvent faire jusqu'au fond de cet air épais où nous sommes, que des plongeons de tres-peu de durée <UP></UP>. Voila donc bien des barrieres naturelles qui nous défendent la sortie de nostre Monde, & l'entrée de celuy de la Lune. Tâchons du moins pour nostre consolation à deviner ce que nous pourrons de ce Monde-là. Je croy, par exemple, qu'il faut qu'on y voye le Ciel, le Soleil, & les Astres d'une autre couleur que nous ne les voyons. Tous ces objets ne nous paroissent qu'au travers d'une espece de Lunette naturelle qui nous les change. Cette Lunette, c'est nostre Air, mêlé comme il est de vapeurs & d'exhalaisons, & qui ne s'étend pas bien haut. Quelques Modernes pretendent que de luy-mesme il est bleu aussi bien que l'eau de la Mer, & que cette couleur ne paroist dans l'un & dans l'autre qu'à une grande profondeur. Le Ciel, disent-ils, où sont attachées les Etoiles Fixes, n'a de luy-mesme aucune lumiere, & par consequent il devroit paroistre noir; mais on le voit au travers de l'Air, qui est bleu, & il paroist bleu. Si cela est, les rayons du Soleil & des Etoiles ne peuvent passer au travers de l'Air sans se teindre un peu de sa couleur, & prendre autant de celle qui leur est naturelle. Mais quand mesme l'Air ne seroit pas coloré de luy-mesme, il est certain qu'au travers d'un gros broüillard, la lumiere d'un flambeau qu'on voit un peu de loin paroist toute rougeâtre, quoy que ce ne soit pas sa vraye couleur, & nostre Air n'est non plus qu'un gros broüillard, qui nous doit alterer la vraye couleur & du Ciel, & du Soleil, & des Etoiles. Il n'appartiendroit qu'à la matiere celeste de nous apporter la lumiere & les couleurs dans toute leur pureté <UP></UP>, & telles qu'elles sont. Ainsi, puis que l'Air de la Lune est d'une autre nature que nostre Air, ou il est teint en luy-mesme d'une autre couleur, ou du moins c'est un autre broüillard qui cause une autre alteration aux couleurs des Corps celestes. Enfin, à l'égard des Gens de la Lune, cette Lunette au travers de laquelle on voit tout, est changée.</P044>
chunks.target_manual: <P034>You would be very Sick, said I, when you were drawn to the top of our Air, for it is not respirable in all its extent, as may be seen on the tops of some <UP>very high</UP> Mountains; and I admire that they who have the folly to believe that our Faries, whom they alow to be Corporeal, and to inhabit the most pure and refin'd Air, do not tell us that the reason why they give us such short and seldom visits, is that there are very few among them that can dive, and those that can, if it be possible to get through the thick Air where we are, cannot stay half so long in it, <UP>as one of the worst of Sir Harry Blount's Sponge- gatherers</UP>. Here then are natural Barricades, which defend the passage out of our World, as well as the Entry into that of the Moon; so that since we can only guess at that World, let us fancy all we can of it. For Example, I will suppose that we may see there the Firmament, the Sun, and the Stars, of another colour than what they are here; all these apear to us through a kind of Natural Spectacles, which change and alter the Objects. These Spectacles are our Air, mix'd as it is with Vapours and Exhalations, and which doth not extend it self very high. Some of our Modern Philosophers pretend, of it self it is blue, as well as the Water of the Sea, and that this colour neither appears in the one nor in the other, but at a great depth; the Firmament, say they, where the fix'd Stars are fastned, hath no peculiar light of its own, and by consequence must appear black, but we see it through the Air which is blue, and therefore to us it appears blue; which if so, the Beams of the Sun and Stars cannot pass through the Air without being ting'd a little with its colour, and losing as much of their own; yet were the Air of no colour, it is very certain, that through a great Mist the light of a Flambeau at some distance appears reddish, though it be not its true natural colour. Our Air is nothing but a great Mist, which changeth the true colour of the Sky, of the Sun, and of the Stars; it belongs only to the Celestial Matter to bring us the Light and Colours as they really are in all the purity; so that since the Air of the Moon is of another nature than our Air, or is stain'd of another colour, or at least is another kind of Mist, which causeth other alterations to the Colours of the Celestial Bodies; in short, as to the People of the Moon, their Spectacles through which they see every thing are chang'd.</P034>

as they really are
explanations: The French 'Genies corporels' (corporeal spirits/geniuses) is rendered as 'our Faries, whom they alow to be Corporeal'. The translator makes the general term 'Genies' explicit by specifying them as 'Faries,' a type of supernatural being deeply embedded in English folklore. This act of specification clarifies the nature of these beings for the target audience by relating them to a familiar cultural concept, thus re-writing the original's more abstract term with a concrete, culturally specific one.

The French phrase 'que des plongeons de tres-peu de durée.' (only dives of very short duration.) is translated with a significant expansion: 'cannot stay half so long in it, as one of the worst of Sir Harry Blount's Sponge- gatherers.' The translator makes the implicit degree of 'very short duration' explicit by adding a highly specific and contemporary simile referencing Sir Harry Blount. This detailed comparison, absent in the original, re-writes the text to provide a vivid, culturally resonant illustration of brevity for the English reader of the period.

The French 'Quelques Modernes' (Some Moderns) is translated as 'Some of our Modern Philosophers.' The translator makes explicit the implied intellectual domain of these 'Moderns' by adding the noun 'Philosophers.' In the context of Fontenelle's work, which popularizes science and philosophy, 'Modernes' refers to contemporary thinkers in these fields, and the addition of 'Philosophers' spells out this assumed understanding for the reader.

The French 'Le Ciel', in the phrase 'Le Ciel, disent-ils, où sont attachées les Etoiles Fixes' (The Sky/Heaven, say they, where the Fixed Stars are attached), is translated as 'the Firmament' in 'the Firmament, say they, where the fix'd Stars are fastned'. The translator makes explicit the specific cosmological concept of the 'Firmament' as the sphere holding the stars, a concept strongly implied by the description of stars being 'attached'. This choice of a more technical term clarifies the historical astronomical model being discussed.

The French 'telles qu'elles sont' (as they are) is translated as 'as they really are.' The translator makes the implicit notion of the fundamental or true nature of light and colors more explicit by inserting the intensifier 'really.' This addition clarifies and emphasizes the distinction between the unaltered state of light and its appearance as modified by Earth's atmosphere.

chunks.source_manual: <P045>Cela me fait préférer nostre sejour à celuy de la Lune, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne saurois croire que l'assortiment des couleurs celestes y soit aussi beau qu'il l'est icy. Mettons, si vous voulez, un Ciel rouge, & des Etoiles vertes, l'effet n'est pas si agreable que des Etoiles couleur d'or sur du bleu. On diroit à vous entendre, <UP></UP>, repris-je, que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble; mais, croyez-moy, la Nature a bien de l'esprit; laissez-luy le soin d'inventer un assortiment de couleurs pour la Lune, & je vous garantis qu'il sera bien entendu. Elle n'aura pas manqué de varier le Spectacle de l'Univers à chaque point de veüe diferent <UP></UP>, & de le varier d'une maniere toûjours agreable.</P045> <P046>Je reconnois son adresse, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle s'est épargné la peine de changer les objets pour chaque point de veüe, elle n'a changé que les Lunettes, & elle a l'honneur de cette grande diversité, sans en avoir fait la dépense. Avec un air bleu, elle nous donne un Ciel bleu, & peut-estre avec un Air rouge, elle donne un Ciel rouge aux Habitans de la Lune, c'est pourtant toûjours le mesme Ciel. Il me paroist qu'elle nous a mis aussi dans l'imagination certaines Lunettes, au travers desquelles on voit tout, & qui changent fort les objets à l'égard de chaque homme. Alexandre voyoit la Terre comme une belle place bien propre à y établir un grand Empire. Celadon ne la voyoit que comme <RW>le sejour d'Astrée</RW>. Un Philosophe la voit comme une grosse Planete qui va par les Cieux, toute couverte de fous. Je ne croy pas que le Spectacle change plus de la Terre à la Lune, qu'il fait icy d'imagination à imagination.</P046>
chunks.target_manual: <P035>If it be so, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I prefer my abode before that of the Moon; for I cannot believe the Celestial Colours are so well suited as they are here; for if you will let us put green Stars on a red Sky, they cannot be so agreable as Stars of Gold on an Azure Firmament. To hear you, said I, one would think you was chusing a <UP>Petticoat, or a suit of Knots; but believe me, Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison</UP>; leave it to her to chuse Colours for the Moon, and I'll engage they shall be well sorted; she will not fail to vary the Prospect of the Universe, at every different point of Sight, and always the Alteration shall be very agreable. I know very well, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, her Skill in this Point; she is not at the charge of changing the Objects, but only the Spectacles, and hath the credit of this great variety, without being at any expence; with a blue Air, she gives us a blue Firmament; and perhaps with a red Air, she gives to the Inhabitants of the Moon a red Firmament; and yet still it is but the same Firmament; nay, I am of opinion, she hath plac'd a sort of Spectacles in our Imagination, through which we see all things, and which to every particular Man change the Objects. Alexander look'd on the Earth as a fit place to establish a great Empire, it seem'd to Celadon a proper residence for Astraea, and it appear'd to a Philosopher, a great Planet in the Heavens, covered with Fools: I do not believe the Sights vary more between the Earth and the Moon, than they do between one Man's Fancy and anothers.</P035>

explanations: The French 'du bleu' (of blue / the blue colour/expanse), in the phrase 'des Etoiles couleur d'or sur du bleu' (gold-coloured stars on blue), implicitly refers to the blue sky as a background. The translation 'an Azure Firmament' makes this explicit by specifying 'Firmament' (the vault of heaven) and using the more specific and poetic 'Azure' for blue, thereby clarifying what constitutes 'the blue'.

The French 'un habit' refers generally to an item of clothing or a garment. The translation 'a Petticoat' makes this far more specific, referring to a particular undergarment worn by women. This explicitation narrows the meaning significantly, tailoring the example to a concrete, culturally understood item, likely to make the comparison more vivid for the contemporary English readership.

The French 'un meuble' means a piece of furniture, a general category. The translation 'a suit of Knots' refers to a specific fashionable decorative item of the period (sets of ribbons or trimmings). This re-writing replaces the general term with a very specific example, explicating the *idea* of choosing something based on aesthetic assortment by providing a concrete, culturally resonant, albeit different, example.

The French 'la Nature a bien de l'esprit' translates to 'Nature has much wit/ingenuity.' The English translation 'Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison' captures the sense of creative ingenuity with 'as good a Fancy,' but the addition 'as Mrs. Harrison' is a clear explicitation. The translator introduces a contemporary cultural reference, presumably to a person known for taste or design, to make Nature's abstract quality more concrete and relatable to the English audience by means of a comparison not present in the original.

The French 'un Ciel bleu' (a blue sky) is translated as 'a blue Firmament.' While 'Ciel' means sky, 'Firmament' is a more specific and formal term for the vault of heaven. This translation makes explicit the understanding of 'Ciel' as the perceived celestial vault rather than just the sky's general blueness, adding a layer of specificity to the description of the sky.

Consistent with the previous instance, translating 'le mesme Ciel' (the same sky) to 'the same Firmament' reinforces the explicitation of 'Ciel' as the specific concept of the celestial vault, rather than simply 'sky' in a more general sense.

The French 'le sejour d'Astrée' means 'the stay/abode/sojourn of Astrée.' The translation 'a proper residence for Astraea' renders 'sejour' as 'residence' and adds the qualifier 'proper.' This addition explicates an implied quality of Astrée's dwelling as fitting or appropriate for the goddess, a nuance potentially inferable from the pastoral context but not explicitly stated in the word 'sejour' itself.

The French 'd'imagination à imagination' (from imagination to imagination) is an abstract expression referring to differing perspectives. The translation 'between one Man's Fancy and anothers' makes this explicit by specifying that 'imagination' here refers to the individual, subjective 'Fancy' (imagination or viewpoint) of different people, grounding the abstract concept in concrete human subjects.

chunks.source_manual: <P047>Le changement de Spectacle est plus surprenant dans nos imaginations, repliquay-je, car ce ne sont que les mesmes objets qu'on voit si diferemment; du moins dans la Lune on peut voir d'autres objets, ou ne pas voir quelques-uns de ceux qu'on voit icy. Peut-estre ne connoissent-ils point en ce Pays-là l'Aurore, ny les Crepuscules, avant que le Soleil se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. L 'Air qui nous environne, & qui est élevé au dessus de nous, reçoit des rayons qui ne pourroient pas tomber sur la Terre, & parce qu'il est fort grossier, il en arreste une partie, & nous les renvoye, quoy qu'ils ne nous fussent pas naturellement destinez. Ainsi l'Aurore & les Crepuscules sont une grace que la Nature nous fait; c'est une lumiere que régulierement nous ne devrions point avoir, & qu'elle nous donne par dessus ce qui nous est dû. Mais dans la Lune, où apparemment l'Air est plus pur, il pourroit bien n'estre pas si propre à renvoyer en bas les rayons qu'il reçoit du Soleil avant qu'il se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. Vous n'avez donc cette lumiere de faveur <NCP></NCP>, qui en se fortifiant peu à peu, vous prepare agreablement à l'arrivée du Soleil, ou qui en s'affoiblissant comme de nuance en nuance, vous accoûtume à sa perte. Vous estes dans des tenebres profondes <NCP></NCP>, & tout d'un coup il semble qu'on tire un rideau, voila vos yeux frapez de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil; vous estes dans une lumiere vive & éclatante, & tout d'un coup vous voila tombés dans des tenebres profondes. Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre. L'Arc-en-ciel est encore une chose qui manque aux Gens de la Lune, car si l'Aurore est un effet de la grossiereté de l'air & des vapeurs, l'Arc-en-ciel se forme dans les nuages d'où tombent les pluyes, & nous devons les plus belles choses du monde à celles qui le sont le moins. Puis <UP></UP> qu'il n'y a autour de la Lune ny vapeurs assez grossieres, ny nuages pluvieux, adieu l'Arc-en-ciel avec l'Aurore, & à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là? Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!</P047>
chunks.target_manual: <P036>This change in our Imaginations, said I, is very surprizing; for they are still the same Objects, tho' they appear different; when in the Moon, we may see other Objects we do not see here, or at least, not see all there we do see here; perhaps in that Country they know nothing of the Dawn and the Twilight, before the Sun riseth, and after the Sun sets; the Air which encompasseth, and is elevated above us, receives the Rays, so that they cannot strike on the Earth; and being gross, stops some of them, and sends 'em to us, tho' indeed they were never naturally design'd us; so that the Day-break and the Twilight are a favour which Nature bestows on us; they are a Light which regularly we should not have, and which she gives us over and above our due; but in the Moon, where apparently the Air is more pure, and therefore not so proper to send down the Beams it receives from the Sun before his rising, and after his setting; you have not that Light of Grace <NCP>(as I may call it)</NCP> which growing greater by degrees, doth more agreably prepare you for the arrival of the Sun, and which growing weaker, and diminishing by degrees, doth insensibly prepare you for the Sun's departure: But you are in a profound darkness, where a Curtain <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> is drawn all on a sudden, your Eyes are immediately dazled with the whole light of the Sun, in all its glory and brightness; so likewise, you are on a sudden surpriz'd with utter Darkness; the Night and the Day have no medium between them, but you fall in a moment from one extreme into the other. The Rainbow likewise is not known to them in the Moon; for if the Dawn is an effect of the grossness of the Air and Vapours, the Rainbow is form'd in the Clouds, from whence the Rain falls; so that the most beautiful things in the World, are produc'd by those things which have no beauty at all. Since then there are no Vapours thick enough, nor no Clouds of Rain about the Moon, farewell Dawn, adieu Rainbow: What must Lovers do for Similies in that Countrey, when such an inexhaustible Magazine of Comparisons is taken from them?</P036>

explanations: The French 'reçoit des rayons qui ne pourroient pas tomber sur la Terre' (receives rays that could not fall on the Earth) can be interpreted in multiple ways regarding the relationship between the reception of rays and their inability to fall on Earth. The English translation 'receives the Rays, so that they cannot strike on the Earth' uses 'so that' to explicitly state a consequential relationship, clarifying that the air's reception of (or interaction with) the rays is the reason they do not directly strike the Earth.

The French links the purity of the air and its properties through juxtaposition: 'où apparemment l'Air est plus pur, il pourroit bien n'estre pas si propre...'. The English translation 'where apparently the Air is more pure, and therefore not so proper...' adds the conjunction 'and therefore,' which explicitly spells out the causal relationship between the air's purity and its reduced capacity to reflect light, a connection that was only implied in the source.

The French 'cette lumiere de faveur' (this light of favor/grace) is translated as 'that Light of Grace (as I may call it)'. The translator's addition of the parenthetical comment '(as I may call it)' is a form of re-writing where they step into the text to explicitly qualify their choice of words or to signal the figurative nature of the expression to the reader, a meta-commentary absent in the original phrase.

The French 'vous accoûtume à sa perte' (accustoms you to its loss) is rendered as 'doth insensibly prepare you for the Sun's departure'. The translator adds 'insensibly,' which makes the manner of this accustoming/preparation explicit. Furthermore, 'prepare you for the Sun's departure' is more specific about the event and the psychological effect than the more general 'accustoms you to its loss,' thus elaborating on the original's implication.

The French 'il semble qu'on tire un rideau' (it seems that one draws a curtain) uses 'il semble' to indicate the metaphorical nature. The English translation 'a Curtain (as it were) is drawn' adds the parenthetical '(as it were)'. This is an explicit marker introduced by the translator to flag the figurative language, making the metaphorical status more overt than the original's 'il semble'.

The French phrase 'de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil' (by all the brilliance/radiance that is in the Sun) is concise. The English translation 'with the whole light of the Sun, in all its glory and brightness' expands on 'l'éclat' by adding the descriptive phrase 'in all its glory and brightness.' This addition explicitly elaborates on the qualities of the Sun's light, providing more descriptive detail than was present in the original.

The French describes two sequential, sudden events: '...tout d'un coup il semble qu'on tire un rideau... & tout d'un coup vous voila tombés dans des tenebres profondes.' The English translation '...your Eyes are immediately dazled...; so likewise, you are on a sudden surpriz'd with utter Darkness;' introduces 'so likewise' to connect the sudden onset of darkness to the preceding sudden onset of light. This explicitly spells out the parallel nature of the two experiences, a relationship that was merely juxtaposed in the original.

The French 'Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre' states that day and night are not linked by an intermediary state. The English translation 'the Night and the Day have no medium between them, but you fall in a moment from one extreme into the other' adds the clause 'but you fall in a moment from one extreme into the other.' This clause explicitly describes the direct experiential consequence for an observer on the Moon, information that was only implied by the absence of a transitional medium in the source text.

The French connects two clauses with '&': 'l'Arc-en-ciel se forme dans les nuages... & nous devons les plus belles choses...'. The English translation renders this as 'the Rainbow is form'd in the Clouds... so that the most beautiful things...'. By changing '&' (and) to 'so that,' the translator makes the logical connection explicit, framing the second clause as a direct consequence or philosophical conclusion derived from the preceding scientific observation.

The French text poses a question about the 'Belles' (Beauties/women) of the Moon and follows with an exclamation: '& à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là? Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!' (And what will the Beauties of that country be like? What a lost source of comparisons!). The English translation 'What must Lovers do for Similies in that Countrey, when such an inexhaustible Magazine of Comparisons is taken from them?' re-writes this significantly by omitting the question about the 'Belles,' specifying 'Lovers' as those affected (an implicit idea made explicit), and greatly expanding 'Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!' into the more elaborate 'when such an inexhaustible Magazine of Comparisons is taken from them?' This makes explicit the richness of the source ('inexhaustible Magazine') and the act of deprivation ('is taken from them').

chunks.source_manual: <P048>Je n'aurois pas grand regret à ces comparaisons là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, & je trouve qu'on est assez bien recompensé dans la Lune <UP></UP>, de n'avoir ny Aurore ny Arc-en- ciel, car on ne doit avoir par la mesme raison ny Foudres ny Tonnerres, puisque ce sont aussi des choses qui se forment dans les nüages. On a de beaux jours toûjours serains pendant lesquels on ne perd point le Soleil de veuë <NCE></NCE>. On n'a point de nuits où toutes les Etoiles ne se montrent <UP></UP>; on ne connoist ny les orages ny les tempestes, ny tout ce qui paroist estre un effet de la colere du Ciel, trouvez-vous qu'on soit tant à plaindre? Vous me faites voir la Lune comme un séjour enchanté, répondis-je; cependant je ne sçay s'il est si délicieux d'avoir toûjours sur la teste, un Soleil ardent dont aucun nüage ne modere la chaleur. Peut-estre aussi est-ce à cause de cela que la Nature a creusé dans la Lune des especes de Puits, qui sont assez grands pour estre apperceus par nos Lunettes; car ce ne sont point des Vallées qui soient entre des Montagnes, ce sont des creux que l'on voit au milieu de certains lieux plats. Que sçait-on si les Habitans de la Lune, incommodez par l'ardeur perpetuelle du Soleil, ne se refugient point dans ces grands Puits? Ils n'habitent peut-estre point ailleurs, c'est-là qu'ils bâtissent leurs Villes. Nous voyons icy que la Rome soûterraine estoit presque aussi grande que la Rome qui estoit sur Terre. Il ne faudroit qu'oster celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la maniere de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples. Vous vous mocquez de cette vision, j'y consens de tout mon cœr; cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plûtost que moy. Vous croyez que les Gens de la Lune doivent habiter sur la surface de leur Planete, parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nostre: c'est tout le contraire, puisque nous habitons sur la surface de nostre Planete, ils pourroient bien n'habiter pas sur la surface de la leur. D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien differentes. <UP></UP></P048>
chunks.target_manual: <P037>I doubt not, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, but there are those in the Moon as good at Simily as <UP>the greatest Beau in Covent-Garden</UP>; and had they neither Sun nor Stars, <NCE>Pearls nor Rubies, Roses nor Lillies</NCE>, yet could say as many fine things to <UP>a Visor-Mask, as the pertest Wit at the Puppet Show</UP>; and they are well enough recompenc'd for the loss of our Dawn and Rainbow; for by the same reason, they have neither Thunder nor Lightning, both which are formed in the Clouds; how glorious are their days, the Sun continually shining? How pleasant their Nights, not the least Star is hid from them? They never hear of Storms or Tempests, which certainly are an effect of the wrath of Heaven: Do you think then they stand in need of our pity? You are describing the Moon, I reply'd, like an enchanted Palace; but do you think it is so pleasant to have a scorching Sun always over our Heads, and not the least Cloud to moderate its Heat? Tho' I fancy 'tis for this reason that Nature hath made great Cavities in the Moon; we can discern 'em easily with our Tellescopes, for they are not Mountains, but so many Wells or Vaults in the middle of a Plain; and what do we know but the Inhabitants of the Moon, being continually broil'd by the excessive heat of the Sun, do retire into those great Wells; perhaps they live no where else, and 'tis there they build 'em Cities; for we still see in the Ruines of old Rome, that that part of the City which was under ground, <UP>was almost as large as that which was above ground. I fancy, during the late siege of Buda, they liv'd there as they do in the Moon, or 'tis but going to the Fountain Tavern Cellar, where the several Vaults are as so many high Streets, the Vats, Pipes, Hogsheads, so many different Edifices, and the Drawers and Coopers, like so many Troglodites</UP>. I perceive you laugh at me, yet if I may be so free with a fair Lady, you deserve it much better than I; for you believe the People in the Moon must live upon the surface of their Planet, because we do so upon ours; but quite contrary, since we dwell upon the Superficies of our Planet, they should not dwell upon the superficies of their Planet; if things differ so much in this World, what must they do in another?</P037>

explanations: The French title "la Marquise" is translated to "the Countess." While "Marquise" has an English equivalent ("Marchioness"), "Countess" is a more common title within the English peerage. The translator likely chose "Countess" to make the character's high social rank immediately and clearly understandable to a contemporary English audience, for whom "Marquise" might have been less familiar. This explicitation clarifies her social standing within the target cultural context by using a more recognizable term.

The translator massively expands the Marquise's simple statement "Je n'aurois pas grand regret à ces comparaisons là" (I wouldn't have much regret for those comparisons). The English version invents a detailed scenario with specific English cultural references of the period (Covent Garden, Visor-Mask, Puppet Show) and elaborates on "comparisons" by depicting witty social discourse. This re-writing adds substantial content not present or implied in the original, aiming to make the Marquise's character and speech more vivid and relatable to the contemporary English audience by explicitly detailing the kinds of 'comparisons' she might be thinking of.

The translator changes the French declarative statements about the pleasant conditions on the Moon ("On a de beaux jours toûjours serains pendant lesquels on ne perd point le Soleil de veuë. On n'a point de nuits où toutes les Etoiles ne se montrent;" - One has beautiful, always serene days... One has no nights where all the stars don't show...) into exclamatory rhetorical questions ("how glorious are their days...? How pleasant their Nights...?"). This stylistic shift makes the Marquise's (Countess's) admiration and the perceived positive aspects of lunar life more explicit and emphatic, thereby re-writing the original's more observational and matter-of-fact tone.

The French phrase "des especes de Puits" (literally "sorts/species of Wells") is translated and expanded to "great Cavities in the Moon... so many Wells or Vaults." While "Puits" translates to "Wells," the translator first introduces the broader term "Cavities" and then offers "Wells or Vaults" as specific interpretations. This expansion adds clarifying information, providing a more detailed and varied visualization of the lunar features by explicitly suggesting alternative forms these "Puits" might take, beyond the singular implication of "Wells."

The translator replaces Fontenelle's more general and imaginative description of a potential subterranean lunar city ("Il ne faudroit qu'oster celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la maniere de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples.") with highly specific, contemporary, and localized analogies. The addition of references to the "late siege of Buda" (1686) and a detailed description of the "Fountain Tavern Cellar" in London, complete with its contents and staff imagined as "Troglodites," is entirely new content. This re-writing makes the abstract idea concrete by explicitly drawing parallels with current events and familiar settings for the English reader, significantly altering the original's mode of illustration.

The translator replaces the philosopher's straightforward phrase "cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plûtost que moy" (however, to speak to you very seriously, you could be mistaken rather than I) with a more elaborate and socially nuanced expression: "yet if I may be so free with a fair Lady, you deserve it much better than I;". The addition "if I may be so free with a fair Lady" introduces an explicit tone of courtly gallantry or polite address common in English society writing of the period, which is not directly stated in the French. Furthermore, "you deserve it much better than I" (implying she deserves to be laughed at) is a more direct and playfully accusatory re-writing of the original's gentler "you could be mistaken."

The original French declarative statement "D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien differentes" (From here to there, all things must be very different) is rephrased as a conditional rhetorical question: "if things differ so much in this World, what must they do in another?". This transformation makes the philosopher's underlying reasoning more explicit by spelling out the logical connection (the observed variability on Earth implies potential differences elsewhere) and the comparative elements ("this World" versus "another" world, i.e., the Moon) that were more concisely implied in the original French.

chunks.source_manual: <P049>Il n'importe, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne puis me resoudre à laisser vivre les Habitans de la Lune dans une obscurité perpetuelle. Vous y auriez encore plus de peine, répris-je, si vous sçaviez qu'un grand Philosophe de l'Antiquité a fait de la Lune le séjour des Ames qui ont merité icy d'estre bien-heureuses. Toute leur felicité consiste en ce qu'elles y entendent l'Harmonie que les Corps Celestes font par leurs mouvemens; mais comme il pretend que quand la Lune tombe dans l'ombre de la Terre, elles ne peuvent plus entendre cette Harmonie <UP></UP>; alors, dit-il, ces Ames crient comme des desesperées, & la Lune se haste le plus qu'elle peut de les tirer d'un endroit si facheux. Nous devrions donc, repliqua-t-elle, voir arriver icy les Bienheureux de la Lune, car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi, & dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde. Serieusement, répris-je, ce ne seroit pas un plaisir mediocre de voir plusieurs Mondes differens. Ce Voyage me réjoüit quelquefois beaucoup à ne le faire qu'en imagination, & que seroit-ce, si on le faisoit en effet? Cela vaudroit bien mieux que d'aller d'icy au Japon, c'est à dire de ramper avec beaucoup de peine d'un point de la Terre sur un autre, pour ne voir que des hommes. Eh bien, dit-elle, faisons le Voyage des Planetes, comme nous pourrons; qui nous en empesche? Allons nous placer dans tous ces differens points de veuê, & de là considerons l'Univers. N'avons-nous plus rien à voir dans la Lune? Je croy que non, répondis-je, du moins je vous y ay fait voir tout ce qui estoit de ma connoissance. Au sortir de la Lune en tirant vers le Soleil, on trouve Venus. Sur Vénus je reprens le <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE>. Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, & autour du Soleil <UP>comme la Lune</UP>, on découvre avec les <NCP><IIM>Lunettes d'approche</IIM></NCP>, que Venus aussi-bien que la Lune, est tantost en Croissant, tantost en Décours, tantost pleine selon les diverses situations où elle est à l'égard de la Terre. La Lune selon toutes les apparences est habitée, pourquoy Vénus ne le sera-t-elle pas aussi? Mais, interrompit-elle, en disant toûjours Pourquoy non, vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planetes? N'en doutez pas, répliquay-je, ce Pourquoy a une vertu qui suffira pour peupler tout. Nous voyons que toutes les Planetes sont de la mesme nature, toutes des Corps <IIM>opaques</IIM> qui ne reçoivent de la lumiere que du Soleil, qui se la renvoyent les uns aux autres, & qui n'ont que les mesmes mouvemens, jusque là tout est égal. Cependant il faudroit concevoir que ces grands Corps auroient esté faits pour n'estre point habitez, que ce seroit là leur condition naturelle, & qu'il y auroit une exception justement en faveur de la Terre toute seule. Qui voudra le croire, le croye; pour moy, je ne m'y puis pas resoudre? Je vous trouve, dit-elle, bien affermy dans vôtre opinion depuis quelques instans. <UP></UP> Je viens de voir le moment que la Lune seroit deserte, & que vous ne vous en souciïez pas beaucoup, & presentement si on osoit vous dire que toutes les Planetes ne sont pas aussi habitées que la Terre, je voy bien que vous vous mettriez en colere. Il est vray, répondis-je, que dans le moment où vous venez de me surprendre, si vous m'eussiez contredit sur les Habitans des Planetes, non seulement je vous les aurois soutenus, mais je crois que je vous aurois dit comment ils estoient tous faits. Il y a des momens pour croire, & je ne les ay jamais si bien crûs que dans celuy là; mais presentement que je suis un peu plus de sens froid, je ne laisse pas de trouver qu'il seroit bien étrange que la Terre fust aussi habitée qu'elle l'est, & que les autres Planetes ne le fussent point du tout; car ne croyez pas que nous voyions tout ce qui habite la Terre; il y a autant d'especes d'Animaux invisibles que de visibles. Nous voyons depuis l'Elephant jusqu'au <UP></UP> Ciron; là finit nostre veuë; mais au Ciron commence une multitude infinie d'Animaux, dont il est l'Elephant, & que la simple veuë ne sçauroit appercevoir. On a vu avec des <RW>Lunettes</RW> beaucoup de Liqueurs toutes remplis de petits Animaux que l'on n'auroit jamais soupçonnez d'y estre, & il y a quelque apparence que le goût qu'elles font sentir, sont les piqueures que ces petits Animaux font à la langue & au palais. Meslez de certaines choses dans quelques-unes de ces Liqueurs, ou exposez-les au Soleil, ou laissez-les se corrompre, voilà aussi-tost de nouvelles especes de petits Animaux.</P049>
chunks.target_manual: <P038>'Tis no matter, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I can never suffer the Inhabitants of the Moon to live in perpetual darkness. You will be more concern'd for 'em, I reply'd, when I tell you that one of the ancient Philosophers did long since discover the Moon to be the abode of the blessed Souls departed out of this Life, and that all their Happiness consisted in hearing the Harmony of the Spheres; <UP>that is, the Musick (I had like to have said Noise) which is made by the motion of the Celestial Bodies; if you have seen a Rar�e Show, you will easily comprehend it: But because the Philosopher pretends to know exactly all they do there, he tells you, that when the Moon is obscur'd by the shadow of the Earth, they no longer hear the Heavenly Musick, but howl like so many Souls in Purgatory</UP>; so that the Moon taking pity of 'em, makes all the haste she can to get into the Light again. Methinks then, says she, we should now and then see some of the Blessed Souls arrive here from the Moon, for certainly they are sent to us. I confess indeed, said I, it would be very pleasant to see different Worlds; such a Voyage, tho' but in Imagination, is very delightful; what would it be in effect? It would be much better certainly than to go to Japan, which at best, is but crawling from one end of the World to t' other, and after all to see nothing but Men. Well then, says she, let us travel over the Planets, as fast as we can; what should hinder us? Let us place our selves at all the different Prospects, and from thence consider the Universe. But first, have we any thing more to see in the Moon? I believe not, I reply'd; at least, you have seen all I can shew you. Coming out of the Moon, towards the Sun, we see Venus, which puts me again in mind of <NCE>Greenwich</NCE>. Venus turns upon her self, and round the Sun, as well as the Moon; they likewise discover by their Tellescopes, that Venus like the Moon, <NCP>(if I may speak after the same manner)</NCP> is sometimes new, sometimes full, and sometimes in the wain, according to the diverse situations she is in, in respect of the Earth.</P038> <P039>The Moon, to all appearance, is inhabited, why should no Venus be so too? You are so full of your Whys, and your Wherefores, says she, interrupting me, that I fancy you are sending Colonies to all the Planets. You may be certain, so I will, I reply'd, for I see no reason to the contrary; we find that all the Planets are of the same nature, all <IIM>obscure</IIM> Bodies, which receive no light but from the Sun, and then send it to one another; their motions are the same, so that hitherto they are alike; and yet if we are to believe that these vast Bodies are not inhabited, I think they were made but to little purpose; why should Nature be so partial, as to except only the Earth? But let who will say the contrary, I must believe the Planets are peopled as well as the Earth. I find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, with some concern, <UP>a Philosopher will never make a good Martyr</UP>, you can so quickly shift your Opinion, 'twas not many minutes since the Moon was a perfect Desart, now the rest of the Planets are inhabited. Why truly, Madam, said I, there is a time for all things, and your true Philosopher believes any thing, or nothing, <UP>as the Maggot bites</UP>. Had you taken me in the <UP>sceptical Vein</UP>, I would have as soon granted a Nation in a Mustard Ball, as a living Creature in the Moon; but the tide is turn'd, and all the Planets are Peopled like an <UP>Anthill</UP>; yet, <UP>Raillery apart</UP>, this is not so very improbable as you think it; for do you believe we discover, (as I may say) all the Inhabitants of the Earth? there be as many kinds of invisible as visible Creatures; we see from the Elephant to the very Hand-worm, beyond which our Sight fails us, and yet counting from that minute Creature, there are an infinity of lesser Animals, which were they perceptible, would be as little in comparison with a Mite, as a Mite is of an Ox. How lately have our <NCE>Virtuoso's</NCE> found out the Pepper Worms, which in the least drop of <RW>Water appear like so many Dolphins, sporting in the Ocean</RW>; nay, they tell you that the sharpness of Vinegar consists in the fierceness of the little Animals that bite you by the Tongue; not to name the blue on Plums, and twenty Experiments of the like nature.</P039>
