explanations: The French 'icy' (here), implicitly referring to the earthly realm from which souls depart, is made explicit as 'departed out of this Life,' clarifying the transition and origin of the souls.

The French description of celestial harmony is expanded. While 'Harmony of the Spheres' is a standard English rendering, the translator adds explicit explanations like 'that is, the Musick (I had like to have said Noise)' and a culturally specific analogy 'if you have seen a Rar�e Show, you will easily comprehend it.' These additions make the concept more accessible and vivid for the English reader, significantly altering the original's more direct statement.

The general French 'comme des desesperées' (like desperate ones) is made explicit and culturally specific by translating it as 'like so many Souls in Purgatory.' This adds a vivid, religiously-tinged image of suffering not explicitly present in the original, drawing on a concept familiar (though potentially controversial) to the English audience.

The French cultural/religious allusion 'le Saint Denis.' (whose relevance to Venus is implicit and potentially obscure) is replaced and explicitated by 'which puts me again in mind of Greenwich.' This grounds the dialogue in a contemporary English scientific context (the Royal Observatory at Greenwich), making the connection to astronomy immediately clear and relevant for the target audience.

The French 'on découvre avec les Lunettes d'approche' (one discovers with approach glasses/spyglasses) is translated as 'they likewise discover by their Tellescopes.' This specifies the instrument more clearly as 'Tellescopes' (relevant to astronomical observation) and the shift from impersonal 'on' to 'they' combined with 'their' makes the agency of the observers (astronomers) more explicit.

The translator adds the parenthetical comment '(if I may speak after the same manner)' when the philosopher describes Venus's phases by analogy to the Moon. This makes the speaker’s awareness of the simplified analogical phrasing explicit, a self-commentary not present in Fontenelle's direct statement, thereby altering the rhetorical style.

The Marquise's question is re-written. 'Pourquoy non' (Why not) is expanded to the idiomatic 'your Whys, and your Wherefores.' More significantly, 'vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planetes?' (you are going to put inhabitants on all the planets for me?) is transformed into 'that I fancy you are sending Colonies to all the Planets.' This introduces a more active and culturally loaded metaphor of colonization that was not explicit in the original, reflecting contemporary English concerns.

The Marquise’s observation of the philosopher's changeability is significantly re-written. The French focuses on his firmness then potential anger ('bien affermy... vous vous mettriez en colere'). The English translation introduces an explicit emotional descriptor for the Countess ('with some concern') and recasts the philosopher's trait into a general, proverbial statement: 'a Philosopher will never make a good Martyr, you can so quickly shift your Opinion,' making an implicit character observation into an explicit, somewhat cynical generalization.

The philosopher's nuanced explanation of his shifting belief ('Il y a des momens pour croire' - There are moments for believing) is extensively re-written with colloquial English idioms and vivid new imagery. Phrases like 'as the Maggot bites,' 'Had you taken me in the sceptical Vein, I would have as soon as granted a Nation in a Mustard Ball, as a living Creature in the Moon,' and 'all the Planets are Peopled like an Anthill' explicitly add a layer of whimsy, cultural specificity, and dramatic exaggeration not present in the more measured French.

The French 'dont il est l'Elephant' (of which it [the mite] is the Elephant), which implies a vast difference in scale, is made explicit. The English translation spells out this implicit relative scale with a more concrete and elaborate analogy: 'which were they perceptible, would be as little in comparison with a Mite, as a Mite is of an Ox,' enhancing the didactic effect.

Fontenelle's general description of microscopic observations is re-written with specific references to contemporary English scientific discoveries and popular imagery. 'On a vu' (One has seen) becomes an explicit attribution to 'our Virtuoso's.' General 'Liqueurs' with 'petits Animaux' are specified as 'Pepper Worms' with the vivid, added simile 'like so many Dolphins, sporting in the Ocean.' The general theory about taste from 'piqueures' (pricks) is exemplified by the specific case of 'sharpness of Vinegar' caused by 'fierceness of the little Animals that bite you by the Tongue.' This grounds the science in recent, culturally relevant English examples, re-writing Fontenelle's more general statements.

The French description of general experimental conditions for observing microorganisms (mixing substances, sun exposure, corruption) is replaced by explicit, concrete examples familiar to the English reader: 'not to name the blue on Plums' (referring to mold) and the generalizing phrase 'and twenty Experiments of the like nature,' alluding to a wider body of contemporary empirical findings by 'Virtuosos' rather than the general processes Fontenelle mentions.

chunks.source_manual: <P050>Beaucoup de Corps qui paroissent solides <UP></UP>, ne sont que des amas de ces Animaux imperceptibles, qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut. Une feüille d'Arbre est un petit Monde habité par des Vermisseaux invisibles, à qui elle paroist d'une étenduë immense, qui y connoissent des Montagnes & des Abismes, & qui d'un costé de la feüille à l'autre n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent, que nous avec nos Antipodes. A plus forte raison, ce me semble, une <RW>grosse</RW> Planete sera-t-elle un Monde habité. On a trouvé jusque dans des especes de pierres tres-dures de petits Vers sans nombre, qui y étoient logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles, & qui ne se nourrissoient que de la substance de ces pierres qu'ils rongeoient. Figurez-vous combien il y avoit de ces petits Vers, & pendant combien d'années ils subsistoient de la grosseur d'un grain de sable; & sur cet exemple, quand la Lune ne seroit qu'un amas de rochers, je la ferois plûtost ronger par ses Habitans que de n'y en pas mettre. Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé <UP></UP>: mettez toutes ces especes d'Animaux nouvellement découvertes, & mesme toutes celles que l'on conçoit aisément qui sont encore à découvrir, avec celles que l'on a toûjours veuës, vous trouverez assurément que la Terre est bien peuplée, & que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vist seulement la moitié. Croirez-vous qu'aprés qu'elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'excés, elle a esté pour toutes les autres Planetes d'une sterilité à n'y rien produire de vivant?</P050> <P051>Ma raison est assez bien convaincuë, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, mais mon imagination est accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & embarrassée de la diversité qu'il faut établir entre eux; car je voy bien que la Nature, selon qu'elle est ennemie des repetitions, les aura tous faits différens, mais comment se representer cela? Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter, répondis-je, elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes. Tous les visages sont en general sur un mesme modele; mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers, & il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille. Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature pour varier en tant de manieres une chose aussi simple qu'un visage? Nous ne sommes dans l'Univers que comme une petite Famille, dont tous les visages se ressemblent; dans une autre Planete, c'est une autre Famille dont les visages ont un autre air. <UP></UP>.</P051> <P052>Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne, & qui verroit un Habitant de la Lune, & un Habitant de la Terre, remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisions qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne. Icy, <NCP>par exemple</NCP>, on a l'usage de la voix, ailleurs on ne parle que par signes, plus loin on ne parle point du tout. Icy le raisonnemét se forme entierement par l'experience; ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose, plus loin les Vieillards n'en sçavent pas plus que les Enfants. Icy on se tourmente de l'avenir plus que du passé; plus loin on ne se tourmente ny de l'un ny de l'autre, & ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux. On dit qu'il pourroit bien nous manquer un sixiéme Sens naturel, qui nous aprendroit beaucoup de choses que nous ignorons. Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde, où il manque quelqu'un des cinq que nous possedons. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il effectivement un grand nombre de Sens naturels; mais dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planetes, il ne nous en est écheu que cinq, dont nous nous contentons faute d'en connoistre d'autres. Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes que l'Esprit humain n'a jamais pû passer; il y a un point où elles nous manquent tout à coup, le reste est pour d'autres Mondes, où quelque chose de ce que nous sçavons est inconnu. <RW>Cette Planete-cy</RW> joüit des douceurs de l'Amour, mais elle est toûjours desolée en plusieurs de ses parties par les fureurs de la Guerre. Dans une autre Planete on joüit d'une Paix éternelle, mais au milieu de cette Paix on ne connoist point l'Amour, & on s'ennuye. Enfin ce que la Nature pratique en petit entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens, elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes, & elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations.</P052>
chunks.target_manual: <P040>Nay, to shew you that they can see <UP>as far into a Milstone as Descartes himself</UP>, they have discover'd that several, even of the most solid Bodies, are nothing but an immense swarm of imperceptible Animals: Do but consider this little Leaf; why it is a great World, of a vast extent, what Mountains, what Abysses are there in it? the Insects of one side, know no more of their fellow Creatures on t' other side, then you and I can tell what they are now doing at the Antipodes; is it not reason then that a great Planet should be inhabited? In the hardest Stones, for Example, in Marble, there are an infinity of Worms, which fill up the vacuums, and feed upon the substance of the Stone; fancy then millions of living Creatures to subsist; many years on a grain of Sand; so that were the Moon but one continued Rock, she should be gnaw'd by these invisible Mites, (as <UP>if she were a green Cheese) rather than not be inhabited: In short, every thing is animated, and the Stones upon Salisbury Plain are as much alive, as a Hive of Bees</UP>; imagine then those Animals which are yet undiscovered, and add them and those which are but lately discover'd, to those we have always seen, you will find the Earth swarms with Inhabitants. Why then should Nature, which is fruitful to an excess here, be so very barren in the rest of the Planets? I must own, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you have convinc'd my Reason, but you have confounded my Fancy, with such variety, that I cannot imagine how Nature, which hates Repetitions, should produce so many different kinds. There is no need of Fancy, I reply'd, do but trust your Eyes, and you will easily perceive how Nature diversifies in these several Worlds.</P040> <P041>All humane Faces, in general, are of the same Model, and yet the Europeans and the Africans have two particular Moulds; nay, commonly every Family have a different Form; what secret then has Nature to shew so much variety in the single Face? Our World, in respect of the Universe, is but a little Family; all whose Faces have some resemblance; in another Place, there is another Family, whose Faces have a different Air and Fashion; <UP>the difference too increaseth with the distance, for whosoever should see an Inhabitant of the Moon, and an Inhabitant of the Earth, would soon perceive they were nearer Neighbours than one of the Earth, and one of Saturn; here, for Example, we have the use of Voice, in another World, they speak by Signs, and at a greater distance they do not speak at all; here our Reason is form'd by Experience, in the next World, Experience contributes little towards it; and in the next to that, old Men know no more than Children; here we are troubled more with what is to come, than with what is past; further off, they are not concern'd with either, which by the way, I think, is much the better: Here, 'tisthought we want a sixth Sense, which would teach us many things, of which we are now ignorant; this sixth Sense, is apparently in another World, where they want one of the five which we enjoy; nay, perhaps there is a much greater number of Senses, but in the Partition we have made of 'em with the Inhabitants of the other Planets, there are but five fall'n to our share, with which we are well contented, for want of being acquainted with the rest: Our Sciences have bounds, which the wit of Man could never pass; there is a point where they fail us on a sudden, the rest is reserv'd for other Worlds, where somewhat which we know, is unknown to them. This Planet enjoys the pleasures of Love, but lies desolate in several places by the fury of War; in another Planet, they enjoy a perpetual Peace, yet in the midst of that Peace, know nothing of Love, and time lies on their hands; in a word, that which Nature practises here in little, in distributing her Gifts among Mankind; she does at large in other Worlds, where she makes use of that admirable secret she hath to diversifie all things, and at the same time makes 'em equal, by compensating for the inequality; this I confess is on the Borders of Nonsense, but a Man is ne'er the less a Philosopher for being a little obscure, if not unintelligible.</UP></P041>

explanations: The translator adds the introductory phrase "Nay, to shew you that they can see as far into a Milstone as Descartes himself, they have discover'd that" before rendering Fontenelle's assertion. This explicitly frames the scientific claim by comparing the discoverers' insight to that of Descartes, adding a layer of interpretation about the significance and intellectual pedigree of such discoveries that is only implied (if at all, by the act of scientific revelation) in Fontenelle's more direct statement.

Fontenelle's description of what the leaf appears to be to the "Vermisseaux" ("à qui elle paroist d'une étenduë immense, qui y connoissent des Montagnes & des Abismes") is re-written by the translator into a series of direct, exclamatory questions ("why it is a great World... what Mountains, what Abysses are there in it?"). This change in rhetorical style makes the implied sense of wonder and vast scale explicit and more directly engaging for the reader.

The general French phrase "des especes de pierres tres-dures" (kinds of very hard stones) is made more explicit by the translator's addition of a specific example, "for Example, in Marble". This clarifies the type of stone Fontenelle refers to by providing a concrete instance not present in the original.

To illustrate the idea of the Moon being "ronger" (gnawed), the translator adds the parenthetical simile "(as if she were a green Cheese)". This explicitation uses a culturally familiar image for the English audience to make Fontenelle's concept more vivid and concrete, an embellishment not found in the source.

The translator expands on Fontenelle's general statement "Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé" (In short, every thing is animated) by adding the specific, culturally resonant English example "and the Stones upon Salisbury Plain are as much alive, as a Hive of Bees". This explicitation grounds the abstract philosophical concept in a concrete, localized image familiar to the English reader, thereby re-writing its presentation.

The French "un autre air" (another look/appearance/manner), referring to the faces of inhabitants on another planet, is translated and expanded to "a different Air and Fashion". The addition of "and Fashion" makes explicit the idea that the differences might include elements of style or deliberate presentation, going beyond the more general "air".

Fontenelle's cautious speculation "& ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux" (and those, perhaps, are not the most unhappy) is re-written by the translator into the explicit, personal opinion "which by the way, I think, is much the better:". This changes the tentative tone of the original to a direct judgment, making the narrator's (or translator's) stance explicit.

The French phrase "que nous possedons" (that we possess), referring to the five senses, is translated as "which we enjoy". The choice of "enjoy" explicitly adds a positive experiential quality and benefit to having senses, a nuance that the more neutral "possedons" implies but does not state as directly.

The concise French expression "on s'ennuye" (one gets bored / they get bored) is expanded into the English idiom "and time lies on their hands;". This explicitation spells out the condition of their boredom (an excess of idle time with nothing to do), which is implied by "s'ennuyer" but not explicitly detailed.

The translator adds an entirely new concluding remark after rendering Fontenelle's sentence: "this I confess is on the Borders of Nonsense, but a Man is ne'er the less a Philosopher for being a little obscure, if not unintelligible." This significant addition is a form of re-writing where the translator (or the adopted persona of the philosopher) explicitly comments on the preceding philosophical speculation, acknowledging its potential obscurity and offering a justification. This self-reflexive commentary is absent from Fontenelle's original text.

chunks.source_manual: <P053>Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.</P053>
chunks.target_manual: <P042>But is it not time, Madam, to be serious, how will you dispose of all these Notions? Trouble not your self, says she, Fancy is a great Traveller; I already comprehend these several Worlds, and represent to my self their different Characters and Customs; some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary; I see at this moment, a thousand different Figures, tho' I cannot well describe 'em. Oh leave 'em, I reply'd, to your Dreams, they will represent 'em very faithfully.</P042>
source_segments: Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.
target_segments: Fancy is a great Traveller
some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary
at this moment
a thousand different Figures
they will represent 'em very faithfully
explanations: The source states the Marquise's imagination "works" (travaille). The translator adds the metaphorical phrase "Fancy is a great Traveller" to explicitly characterize the nature of this imaginative work as dynamic, active, and wide-ranging (like a traveller), an aspect that was only implied by the general verb "travaille" (works).

The source describes "extraordinaire Caracteres & Coûtumes" (extraordinary Characters & Customs). The target translation adds the emphatic phrase "some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary". This addition makes the Marquise's personal conviction and the intensity of her imaginative experience more explicit by adding direct assertion ("I assure you") and intensifiers ("very") not present in the more declarative source.

The source uses the present tense "Je me represente" (I represent to myself/I am imagining), implying a current, ongoing mental action. The target phrase "at this moment" (in "I see at this moment") explicitly spells out the immediacy of her vision, adding a temporal clarifier that was only implied by the verb tense in French.

The source describes "des figures tout-à-fait bizarres" (quite bizarre figures) and the Marquise later mentions seeing "quelque chose" (something). The target translates this vision as "a thousand different Figures," thereby making the perceived quantity (hyperbolically "a thousand") and variety ("different") of these figures explicit, expanding on the more general qualitative or indefinite descriptions in the source.

The source proposes a future, conditional verification of dreams' utility ("Nous verrons demain s'ils...auront appris..." - We will see tomorrow if they...will have taught...). The target replaces this open-ended inquiry with a declarative assertion: "they will represent 'em very faithfully." This explicitly attributes a definitive capability (faithful representation) to dreams, a quality that was only implied as a possibility to be explored in the source, thus spelling out an assumed function.

chunks.source_manual: <P054>QUATRIEME SOIR.</P054>
chunks.target_manual: <P044>The Fourth Evening.</P044>
target_segments: The Fourth Evening.
explanations: The French heading 'QUATRIEME SOIR.' (Fourth Evening.) omits an explicit definite article, a common practice for such titles in French where definiteness is implied by the ordinal and context. The English translation 'The Fourth Evening.' adds the article 'The', making this implied definiteness explicit. This formally expands the condensed source expression by adding an explicit grammatical marker of definiteness; this is a translator's choice as alternative English title formats (e.g., 'Fourth Evening.') without the article would also be grammatically acceptable.

chunks.source_manual: <P055><SC>Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.</SC> Nous en estions à Venus. On est bien seur, dis-je à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, <SC>mais on ne sçait pas bien en quel temps</SC>, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années, elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroist une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy; & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, elle paroist dedans Venus à peu prés de la mesme grandeur dont Venus nous paroist d'icy.</P055>
chunks.target_manual: <P045><UP>I Have been told of a Physician that makes his Patients dream as he pleases, by prescribing such a Specifick for their Supper, as works those impressions he would have on the Fancy; of what use he may be to the modern Poets, I leave to the curious; and return to the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, who either did not dream at all, or nothing to the purpose</UP>; so that continuing our Voyage to the other Worlds, we could only guess at their Inhabitants. We were come to Venus, and I told her, that Venus certainly turn'd on it self, tho' no body could tell in what time, and consequently were ignorant how long her Day lasted; but her Year was compos'd of eight Months, because 'tis in that time she turns round the Sun: And seeing Venus is forty times less than the Earth, the Earth appears (to them in Venus) to be a Planet, forty times bigger than Venus appears to us on the Earth; and as the Moon is forty times lesser than the Earth, so she seems to be just of the same magnitude, to the Inhabitants of Venus, as here Venus seems to us.</P045>
source_segments: Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy.
target_segments: the Countess, who either did not dream at all, or nothing to the purpose
(to them in Venus)
on the Earth
to the Inhabitants of Venus
explanations: The French text states that "Les songes ne furent point heureux" (The dreams were not at all happy/successful) and explains this by adding "ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy" (they always represented something that resembled what one sees here). The English translation makes two aspects explicit: 1) It attributes the dreams directly to "the Countess" (the translator's term for the Marquise), whose dreams are implicitly being discussed. 2) The phrase "nothing to the purpose" explicitly states the negative evaluation or lack of utility of these unoriginal dreams for their goal of imagining extraterrestrial life, an evaluation which is implied in the French text by the description of the dreams' content following the statement that they "ne furent point heureux".

The French phrase "de dedans Venus" (from within Venus), describing how Earth appears, implies an observer located on Venus. The English translation "(to them in Venus)" makes this implied observer explicit by adding "to them", thereby clarifying that it is the hypothetical inhabitants of Venus (referred to as "them") who are the ones perceiving Earth from Venus.

The French deictic adverb "d'icy" (from here) in the phrase "que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy" (than Venus appears to us from here) contextually refers to Earth. The English translation "on the Earth" makes this implicit location explicit by specifically naming Earth as the vantage point.

The French phrase "dedans Venus" (from/within Venus), used in "elle paroist dedans Venus" to describe the Moon's appearance, implies an observation point or an observer on Venus. The English translation clarifies this by explicitly naming the observers as "to the Inhabitants of Venus", specifying who is perceiving the Moon from Venus.

chunks.source_manual: <P056>Vous m'affligez, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroist trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroist de la mesme grandeur dont Vénus nous paroist d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y estre Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger <NCE></NCE>. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une petite Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. <UP></UP> C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Venus; ces Gens là doivent bien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Venus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. <UP></UP> Le climat est tres-favorable aux Amours. Venus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.</P056>
chunks.target_manual: <P046>I see then, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, that the Earth is not to Venus, what Venus is to the Earth; I mean, that the Earth is too bigg to be the Mother of Love, or the Shepherd's Star to Venus; but the Moon, which appears to Venus, of the same bigness that Venus appears to us, is assign'd to be the Mother of Love, and <NCE>Shepherds Star to Venus</NCE>; for such names are only proper for a little brisk airy Planet, bright, and shining as the Goddess her self. Oh, blessed Moon, how happy art thou, to preside over the Amours of those gallant People, where all they say, is soft and moving, <UP>and perfectly refin'd from the dross of our Wits, who are fitter for a Bear-Garden than a Circle? How gross is their Courtship? how mean their Raillery? without any distinction of time, place, or person; they make Love, (as they call it) but one way, and the form is the same, at a Farce, or Funeral. Be not so very severe, I reply'd, if some of our Beaux speak plain English, some of your Belles, like 'em ne're the worse for't: The art of Love is as much improv'd as the art of War, the Generals of this Age take a Town in two days, which in the last, held out as many years; and the Roses, Lillies, Pearls, and Rubies, (a whining Lovers train of Artillery)</UP> are grown as useless as Bows and Arrows: tho' after all, I must own they have another Standard in the Planet Venus; there <UP>Clelia</UP> and Parthenissa, is below the language of Grooms and Chamber Maids; and every Porter and Car-Man a perfect Sir Courtly; but then consider the difference of Climats; Venus is much nearer than the Earth is to the Sun, from whence she receives a more vigorous and active influence.</P046>

brisk airy

where all they say, is soft and moving, and perfectly refin'd from the dross of our Wits, who are fitter for a Bear-Garden than a Circle? How gross is their Courtship? how mean their Raillery? without any distinction of time, place, or person; they make Love, (as they call it) but one way, and the form is the same, at a Farce, or Funeral.

Be not so very severe, I reply'd, if some of our Beaux speak plain English, some of your Belles, like 'em ne're the worse for't: The art of Love is as much improv'd as the art of War, the Generals of this Age take a Town in two days, which in the last, held out as many years; and the Roses, Lillies, Pearls, and Rubies, (a whining Lovers train of Artillery) are grown as useless as Bows and Arrows: tho' after all, I must own they have another Standard in the Planet Venus; there Clelia and Parthenissa, is below the language of Grooms and Chamber Maids; and every Porter and Car-Man a perfect Sir Courtly;

explanations: The French "car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroist trop grande" (for the Earth seen from Venus appears too large) introduces the reason why the Earth cannot fulfill certain poetic roles for Venus. The English translation prefaces this explanation with "I mean,", making the Marquise's process of reasoning and clarification more explicit. This spells out that the following clause is a direct explanation of her preceding assertion about the Earth's role relative to Venus.

The French adjective "jolie" (pretty), part of the description "une petite Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante" (a little planet that is pretty, clear, shining), is expanded in the English translation "a little brisk airy Planet" by the addition of "brisk airy." These adjectives are not direct translations of "jolie" but are inserted by the translator to explicitly characterize the planet with specific qualities of liveliness ("brisk") and gracefulness/lightness ("airy"), thereby elaborating on the general idea of "pretty" with more vivid detail.

The French "qui ait un air galant" (that has a gallant/charming air) describes a quality of the planet. The English translation, in the phrase "bright, and shining as the Goddess her self," makes the implicit cultural connection to Venus, the goddess of love and beauty (the planet's namesake), explicit by adding the comparison "as the Goddess her self." This clarifies the standard of gallantry or charm being invoked.

The French declarative statement "C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Venus" (It is certainly an agreeable destiny for our Moon to preside over the Amours of the Inhabitants of Venus) is re-written in the English translation as an apostrophe: "Oh, blessed Moon, how happy art thou, to preside over the Amours of those gallant People,". This re-writing makes the implied positive emotion of "destinée agréable" explicit and greatly amplifies it through direct address and heightened language ("blessed," "happy"), altering the rhetorical style.

The concise French assertion "doivent bien entendre la galanterie" (must indeed understand gallantry), referring to the inhabitants of Venus, is massively expanded in the English translation. The translator adds a long, explicit description of *how* Venusians supposedly practice gallantry, primarily by contrasting it with a satirical portrayal of perceived deficiencies in contemporary (implied English) social manners ("dross of our Wits," "Bear-Garden," "gross Courtship"). This extensive added section provides detailed, culturally-specific clarifying information and social commentary not present in the source.

Fontenelle's philosopher responds to the Marquise with a brief agreement, using French pastoral and romance literary allusions ("Celadons & de Silvandres," "Clesie"). The English translator entirely re-writes this response. The philosopher's speech is expanded into a lengthy aside that includes a defense of some aspects of English courtship, introduces a novel analogy between the "art of Love" and the modern "art of War" with specific examples, and then describes Venusian gallantry using contemporary English literary ("Clelia and Parthenissa") and social archetypal ("Grooms and Chamber Maids," "Sir Courtly") references. This extensive addition explicitly adapts the dialogue to an English cultural context, adding layers of social commentary, satire, and culturally specific examples far beyond the original's scope.

The French phrase "une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur" (a more vivid light and more heat) provides a direct physical description of what Venus receives from the Sun. The English translation "a more vigorous and active influence" makes the implied *effect* of this increased light and heat on the inhabitants or environment of Venus explicit. It shifts from a simple description of physical properties to an interpretation of their impact, suggesting a broader, more energetic consequence beyond just light and heat.

chunks.source_manual: <P057>Je vois presentement, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, comment sont faits les Habitans de Venus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, repliquay-je, que vous ne connoissez guere bien les Habitans de Venus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient esté auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.</P057>
chunks.target_manual: <P047>I find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, it is easie enough to guess at the Inhabitants of Venus; they resemble what I have read of the Moors of Granada, who were a little black People, scorch'd with the Sun, witty, full of Fire, very Amorous, much inclin'd to Musick and Poetry, and ever inventing Masques and Turnaments in honour of their Mistresses. Pardon me, Madam, said I, you are little acquainted with the Planet; Granada in all its Glory, was a perfect Greenland to it; and your gallant Moors, in comparison with that People, were as stupid as so many Laplanders.</P047>
source_segments: inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois
target_segments: they resemble what I have read of the Moors of Granada
and ever inventing Masques and Turnaments in honour of their Mistresses
Granada in all its Glory
your gallant Moors
explanations: The translator adds the phrase 'what I have read of,' making explicit the source of the Marquise's knowledge about the Moors of Granada. The original French, 'Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins' (They resemble the Grenadine Moors), implies she has a certain image or knowledge of them. The translation specifies that this knowledge likely comes from reading, thereby clarifying an aspect of her character's thought process or cultural background which was implicit in the source.

The translator makes the description more specific and elaborates on the motivation. Firstly, 'Festes, des Danses' (Festivals, Dances) in the source 'inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois' (inventing every day Festivals, Dances, & Tournaments) is partly rendered as 'Masques,' a specific and fashionable form of courtly entertainment from that era. This makes explicit a likely type of festivity implied by the general term 'Festes.' Secondly, the phrase 'in honour of their Mistresses' is added. This explicitly links their inventive activities to courtly love, a connection merely implied in the source by the Venusians' 'toûjours amoureux' (always amorous) nature.

In the philosopher's reply, the source's 'Nos Mores Grenadins' (Our Grenadine Moors) is partly rendered as 'Granada in all its Glory' when establishing a comparison with Greenland ('Granada in all its Glory, was a perfect Greenland to it'). This phrasing explicitly evokes the historical peak and cultural splendor of Moorish Granada. This information might be inferred by Fontenelle's educated readers from the reference to 'Mores Grenadins,' but the translator spells it out, adding historical vividness and clarifying the basis of the comparison.

Referring again to 'Nos Mores Grenadins' in the philosopher's comparative statement, the translator uses the phrase 'your gallant Moors' ('and your gallant Moors, in comparison with that People, were as stupid as so many Laplanders'). The addition of the adjective 'gallant' makes explicit a characteristic (chivalry, courtliness). This trait was strongly implied by the Marquise's preceding description of the Moors (amorous, poetic, festive, etc.) but was not directly stated by Fontenelle in this specific comparative context. The translator spells out this assumed trait.

chunks.source_manual: <P058>Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. <UP></UP> Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de memoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvemens subits, & <IIM>qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.</IIM> <NCE></NCE> Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoye une lumiere si forte, que s'ils estoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de <IIM>tres-foibles</IIM> Crepuscules, & peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un <RW>grand poêle ardent</RW>, peu éloigné de leurs testes, & qui va d'une rapidité prodigieuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent aprés la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Venus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroistre assez grandes. Pour les autres Planetes, comme elles sont au-delà de la <IIM>Terre vers le Firmament</IIM>, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumiere, peut-estre n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien fàché de voir cette <RW>grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient</RW>, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. <SC></SC>.</P058>
chunks.target_manual: <P048>But what do you think then of the Inhabitants of Mercury? They are yet nearer to the Sun, and are so full of Fire, <UP>that they are absolutely mad; I fancy, they have no memory at all, like most of the Negroes, that they make no reflections, and what they do is by sudden starts, and perfect hap-hazard; <NCE>in short, Mercury is the Bedlam of the Universe</NCE>; the Sun appears to them much greater than it does to us, because they are much nearer to it than we; it sends them so vast and strong a light, that the most glorious day here, would be no more with them than a declining Page 97 twilight: I know not if they can distinguish Objects, but the heat to which they are accustom'd, is so excessive, that they would be starved with cold in the Torrid Zone; their year is but three Months, but we know not the exact length of their Day, because Mercury is so little, and so near the Sun; it is, (as it were) lost in his Rays, and is very hardly discover'd by the Astronomers; so that they cannot observe how it moves on its Centre, but because it is so little, fancy it compleats its motion in a little time; so that by consequence, the day there is very short, and the Sun appears to them like <RW>a vast fiery Furnace at a little distance</RW>, whose motion is prodigiously swift and rapid; and during their Night, Venus and the Earth (which must appear considerably big) give light to them; as for the other Planets which are beyond the Earth, <RW>towards the Firmament</RW>, they appear less to them in Mercury, than they do to us here, and they receive but little light from them, perhaps none at all; the fix'd Stars likewise seem less to them, and some of 'em totally disappear, which were I there, I should esteem a very great</UP> loss. <SC></SC></P048>

c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.
ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons

explanations: The French "à force de vivacité" (by dint of/due to an excess of vivacity) implies madness results from an intense liveliness. The translation "so full of Fire" makes this more explicit by attributing their state to an abundance of "Fire," a specific elemental quality, thereby adding a clarifying layer about the nature of this "vivacité" and its connection to their madness.

The French "les Petites Maisons de l'Univers" refers to "the madhouses of the Universe" (plural). The translation "Mercury is the Bedlam of the Universe" uses a specific English cultural equivalent ("Bedlam") and alters the construction to identify Mercury singularly *as* "the Bedlam," implying it is the principal or sole such institution for the cosmos. This makes the metaphorical identification more direct, explicit, and emphatic.

The French "au fond de l'Afrique" (deep in Africa) evocatively suggests an extremely hot region. The translation "in the Torrid Zone" replaces this general, somewhat literary description with a specific and formal scientific/geographical term. This explicitation clarifies the reference by using terminology current in the burgeoning scientific discourse of the era, making the comparison more precise for an educated readership.

The French "un grand poêle ardent" (a large, burning stove/furnace) is translated to "a vast fiery Furnace." The addition of "vast" explicitly intensifies the size beyond what "grand" (large) alone conveys, and the overall phrase paints a more explicitly grandiose and intense image of the sun for the inhabitants of Mercury.

The French "d'une rapidité prodigieuse" (with a prodigious rapidity), part of a clause describing the sun's movement, uses a noun phrase. The translation "prodigiously swift and rapid" expands this by using a doublet of adjectives ("swift and rapid"). This expansion makes the quality of extreme speed more explicitly detailed and rhetorically emphasized.

The French "pendant ce temps-là" (during that time) implicitly refers to the night, which is contextually understood as the period the inhabitants of Mercury are said to long for. The translation "during their Night" makes this reference explicit by directly naming "Night," thus spelling out the temporal connection that was previously left for the reader to infer from context.

The French "ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons" (they see them smaller than we see them) implies the observational standpoints (Mercury for "ils"/they, Earth for "nous"/we) from the dialogue's broader context. The translation "they appear less to them in Mercury, than they do to us here" makes these standpoints explicit by adding the prepositional phrases "in Mercury" and "to us here," thereby clarifying the comparative perspectives by spelling out the unstated locations.

The French "c'est, selon moy, une perte" (it is, in my opinion, a loss) is a straightforward statement of opinion. The translation "which were I there, I should esteem a very great loss" re-writes this by introducing a hypothetical condition ("were I there"), making explicit the imagined perspective from which the judgment is made. Additionally, it intensifies "une perte" (a loss) to "a very great loss," explicitly heightening the perceived severity of the loss.

chunks.source_manual: <P059>Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, de cette perte-là que sont les <IIM>Habitans de Mercure</IIM>, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de la chaleur. Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu. Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraischissent, comme on dit qu'il en tombe icy dans les Pays chauds pendant des quatre mois entiers, justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes.</P059> <P060>Cela se peut, repris-je, & mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon. Il y a des Pays dans la Chine qui doivent estre tres-chauds par leur situation, & où il fait pourtant de grands froids pendant les mois de Juillet & d'Aoust, jusque-là que les Rivieres se gelent. C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance. Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM>, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire. Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre, & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement. Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM> & des pluyes.</P060>
chunks.target_manual: <P049>What signifies the loss of a few fix'd Stars, says the <IIM>Countess?</IIM> I pity 'em for the excessive heat <SC>they </SC> endure; let us give 'em some relief, and send Mercury a few of the refreshing Showers they have sometimes four Months together in the hottest Countries during their greatest extremity. Your Fancy is good, Madam, I reply'd, but we will relieve 'em another way; In China there are Countries which are extreamly hot by their Situation: yet in July and August are so cold, that the Rivers are Frozen; the reason is, they are full of Salt-Petre, which being exhal'd in great abundance by the excessive heat of the Sun, makes a perfect Winter at Midsummer. We will fill the little Planet with Salt-petre, and let the Sun shine as hot as he pleases. And yet after all, who knows but the Inhabitants of Mercury may have no occasion either for Rain, or Salt- Petre. If it is a certain truth, that Nature never gives life to any Creature, but where that Creature may live; then thro' Custom, and ignorance of a better Life, those People may live happily.</P049>
source_segments: & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement
target_segments: the loss of a few fix'd Stars
the excessive heat of the Sun
then thro' Custom, and ignorance of a better Life, those People may live happily
explanations: The French "cette perte-là" (that loss) is a deictic reference occurring within the phrase "de cette perte-là que sont les Habitans de Mercure" (of that loss that the Inhabitants of Mercury experience). It refers to a loss previously discussed or understood in the dialogue. The English translation "the loss of a few fix'd Stars" makes this specific loss explicit by naming it, adding clarifying information that was only implied or relied on the reader's prior knowledge from the text.

The French phrase "la force de la chaleur" (the force/strength of the heat) is translated into English as "the excessive heat of the Sun." The translator has made this more explicit by: 1) identifying "the Sun" as the specific source of the heat, which was implied but not stated in the French phrase, and 2) adding the adjective "excessive" to qualify the heat, thus elaborating on the general term "la force" (the force/strength).

The French text states "Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que [Assertion A: la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre] & que [Assertion B: l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement]" (It is certain that [A] and that [B occurs and makes them live there pleasantly]). The English translation recasts this structure into an explicit conditional: "If it is a certain truth, that [Assertion A]; then [Assertion B results in people living happily]." The use of "then" to introduce the target segment explicitly frames Assertion B as a consequence or logical outcome of Assertion A, a relationship that was less formally spelled out by the French conjunction "& que" (and that) and the verb "survient" (arises/ensues).

chunks.source_manual: <P061>Aprés Mercure vous sçavez qu'on trouve le Soleil. Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans. Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là. Nous jugeons par la Terre qui est habitée, que les autres Corps de la mesme espece qu'elle, doivent l'estre aussi; mais le Soleil n'est point un Corps de la mesme espece que la Terre, ny que les autres Planetes. Il est la source de toute cette lumiere que les Planetes ne font que se renvoyer les unes aux autres, aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy. Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles, mais elles ne la peuvent produire. Luy seul tire de soy-mesme cette pretieuse substance; il la pousse avec force de tous costez; de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide, & d'une Planete à l'autre il s'épand de longues & vastes traisnées de lumieres qui se croisent & se traversent, & s'entrelassent en mille façons diferentes, & forment d'admirables tissus de la plus riche matiere qui soit au monde. Aussi le Soleil est-il placé dans le centre, qui est le lieu le plus commode d'où il la puisse distribuer également, & animer tout par sa chaleur <NCP></NCP>. Le Soleil est donc un Corps <UP>particulier</UP>, mais quelle sorte de Corps? On est bien embarrassé à le dire. On avoit toûjours crû que c'estoit un feu tres-pur, mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce <IIM>Siecle</IIM>, qu'on apperceut des taches sur sa surface. Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le <IIM>Monde Philosophe</IIM> n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient; <UP>qu'elles avoyent un mouvement autour du Soleil</UP>, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous. Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...</P061>
chunks.target_manual: <P050>After Mercury comes the Sun, but there is no possibility of peopling it, nor no room left for a wherefore. By the Earth which is inhabited, we judge that other Bodies of the same Nature may be likewise inhabited; but the Sun is a Body not like the Earth or any of the Planets, the Sun is the source or Fountain of Light, which tho' it is sent from one Planet to another, and receives several alterations by the way, yet all originally proceeds from the Sun, he draws from himself that precious substance which he emits from all sides, and which reflects when it meets with a solid Body, and spreads from one Planet to another those long and vast trains of Light which cross, strike thro', and intermingle in a thousand different fashions, and make <NCP>(if I may so say,)</NCP> the Richest Tissu's in the World. The Sun likewise is placed in the Centre, from whence with most convenience, he may equally distribute and animate by his heat; it is then a particular Body, <UP>but what sort of Body has often puzled better heads than mine</UP>. It was thought formerly a Body of pure Fire, and that Opinion passed currant till the beginning of this Age; when they perceived several spots on its surface. A little after they had discover'd new Planets, (of which, hereafter) which some said were those Spots; for those Planets moving round the Sun, when they turned their dark half to us, must necessarily hide part of it; and had not the Learned with these pretended Planets made their Court before to most of the Princes in Europe, giving the name of this Prince to one, and of that Prince to another Planet; I believe they would have quarrel'd who should be Master of these spots, that they might have nam'd them as they pleas'd.</P050>

explanations: The French "la source" (the source) is translated as "the source or Fountain". The addition of "or Fountain" expands the original term by offering a more vivid and slightly poetic synonym. This makes the concept of origin more emphatic and elaborate than the concise French, an explicitation by expansion.

The French states that planets exchange light ("se renvoyer les unes aux autres") after receiving it from the sun ("aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy."). The English translation elaborates on this process by adding the clause "and receives several alterations by the way," explicating a physical detail about the light's journey that is not present in the original French text. Furthermore, the concluding phrase "yet all originally proceeds from the Sun" emphatically reinforces the sun's role as the ultimate origin, spelling out this consequence more directly than the original.

The French "il la pousse avec force de tous costez" (he pushes it with force from all sides) uses the general, dynamic verb "pousse" (pushes). The English translation "which he emits from all sides" uses the more specific term "emits," which is standard for describing the release of light or radiation. This makes the scientific process more explicit by employing a more technical and precise verb.

The French "de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide" (from there it returns to meet/encounter all that is solid) is translated as "and which reflects when it meets with a solid Body". The translation replaces the general phrase "revient à la rencontre" (returns to meet/encounter) with the specific optical term "reflects." This explicates the precise physical mechanism of light interacting with solid bodies, which was only generally implied in the source.

The impersonal French "On est bien embarrassé à le dire" (One is very puzzled/embarrassed to say it) is rendered as the personal and self-deprecating "has often puzled better heads than mine." The translator makes the general intellectual difficulty explicit through the comparison "better heads" and introduces a personal voice ("than mine"), changing the rhetorical stance from an objective statement of difficulty to a more subjective admission of the challenge, thereby re-writing the authorial/narratorial persona.

The French "mais on s'en desabusa" (but one was disabused of it) indicates the point of correction of a belief. The English translation rephrases this by stating "and that Opinion passed currant till [the point of correction]", thereby explicitly adding the detail that the previous belief "passed currant" (i.e., was generally accepted) before being overturned. This explicates the status and duration of the former belief which was only implied in the French.

The French "on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient" (it was immediately judged/one immediately judged that these spots were them [the new planets]) uses the impersonal "on jugea," suggesting a general or collective judgment. The English translation "which some said were those Spots" narrows this down by attributing the judgment to "some." This explicates that the idea was not necessarily a universally accepted conclusion at the time but rather a viewpoint held by a specific, albeit undefined, group, thus qualifying the certainty or pervasiveness of the judgment.

The French describes an ongoing action ("Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour...") and then speculates on a possible future quarrel ("& peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle..."). The English translation significantly re-writes this by introducing a counterfactual conditional structure ("had not the Learned... made their Court before...") and explicitly inserting the translator's personal reasoning ("I believe they would have quarrel'd..."). This spells out a causal relationship—that the prior act of naming planets for princes potentially averted or altered a quarrel over naming sunspots—which is an interpretation and elaboration by the translator, making an unstated connection explicit and altering the narrative framing.

chunks.source_manual: <P062>Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes, & j'en estois fort contente. Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Sçavans se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres. Souffrez, répondis-je, <UP></UP> qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune. Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage. Il se trouva que ce n'estoient point des Planetes, mais des nuages, des fumées, des écumes, qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil. Elles sont tantost en grande quantité, tantost en petit nombre; tantost elles disparoissent toutes, quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires. Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup, il y en a d'autres, & mesme assez longs, où il n'en paroist aucune. Il semble que le Soleil soit une matiere liquide, quelques-uns disent de l'Or fondu, qui boüillonne incessamment <NCP></NCP>, & produit des impuretez, qui par la force de son mouvement sont rejettées sur sa surface. Elles s'y consument, & puis il s'en produit d'autres. Imaginez-vous quels Corps étrangers ce sont là. Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre aussi grand que la Terre. Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil. D'autres disent que le Soleil paroît avec des Lunettes tout plein de Montagnes qui vomissent des flâmes, & que c'est comme un million de Monts Etna mis ensemble, mais on dit aussi que ces Montagnes sont une pure vision, causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes. Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes mesme, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects. Enfin, quoy que ce puisse estre que le Soleil, il ne paroist nullement propre à estre habité. C'est pourtant dommage, l'habitation seroit belle. On seroit au centre de tout, on verroit toutes les Planetes tourner regulierement autour de soy, au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizareries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement. Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable? Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse estre extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne. Vous n'y songez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Qui seroit dans le Soleil, verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes. Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout? Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature.</P062>
chunks.target_manual: <P051>'Twas but t'other day, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you were describing the Moon, and call'd several places by the names of the most famous Astronomers. I was pleased with the fancy; for since the Princes have seiz'd on the Earth; 'tis fit the Philosophers should reserve the Heavens for themselves without any Competitors. Oh! trouble not your self, said I, <UP>the Philosophers make the best advantage of their Territories; and if they part with the least Star, 'tis on very good terms; let me tell you, an Acre of Land in England, is worth ten thousand in the Moon, but the spots on the Sun are fallen to nothing; the actions of Pensilvania are not half so low</UP>, 'tis now discover'd that they are not Planets, but Clouds, Steams, or Dross, which rise upon the Sun, sometimes in great quantity, sometimes in less; sometimes they are dark, sometimes clear, sometimes they continue a great while, and sometimes they disappear as long. It seems the Sun is a Liquid Matter, some think of melted Gold, which boils over <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> continually, and by the force of its motion casts the Scum or dross on its surface, where it is consumed, and others arise. Imagine then what strange Bodies these are, when some of 'em are as big as the Earth; What a vast quantity must there be of this melted Gold, and what must be the extent of this great Sea of Light and Fire which they call the Sun? Others say, the Sun appears through their Tellescopes, full of Mountains which vomit Fire continually, and are joyn'd together like millions of Etna's. Yet there are those who say these burning Mountains are pure Vision, caus'd by a fault in the Spectacles; but what shall we trust, if we must distrust our Tellescopes to which we owe the knowledge of so many new Objects? But let the Sun be what it will, it cannot be at all proper for habitation; and what pity 'tis not, for how pleasant would it be? You might then be at the Centre of the Universe, where you would see all the Planets turn regularly about you; but now we know nothing but extravagant Page 103 fancies, because we do not stand in the proper place; there is but one place in the World where the study or knowledge of the Stars is easily obtain'd, and what pity 'tis there is no body there. You forget your self sure, says she, were you in the Sun you would see nothing, neither Planets nor fix'd Stars, doth not the Sun efface all? so that could there be any Inhabitants there, they might justly think themselves the only people in Nature.</P051>

explanations: The French source mentions philosophers potentially 'engaging' (pledging or mortgaging) celestial bodies to princes 'in case of need.' The English translation re-writes and significantly expands this by adding substantial new information: asserting that philosophers 'make the best advantage of their Territories,' ensure transactions are 'on very good terms,' and providing a concrete, culturally-specific economic comparison ('an Acre of Land in England, is worth ten thousand in the Moon'). These additions explicitly spell out the supposed shrewdness and the illustrative financial terms of such an engagement, details entirely unstated in the source, thereby re-writing the passage for the target audience.

The original French 'ils n'en purent faire aucun usage' simply states that 'they could make no use of them' (referring to sunspots). The English translation re-writes this by first using the more emphatic 'are fallen to nothing' and then adding an entirely new, contemporary economic analogy: 'the actions of Pensilvania are not half so low.' This addition explicitly contextualizes the abstract idea of 'no use' or 'no value' in financial terms that would be familiar and resonant to an English reader of that period, thus re-writing the original to provide a specific, cultural reference point.

The general French term 'des impuretez' (impurities), referring to what rises from the sun's surface, is translated using the more specific English terms 'Scum or dross.' This explicitation clarifies the *type* of impurities being described, making the connection to the preceding analogy of 'melted Gold' more direct and vivid for the reader.

The French 'des Lunettes' (from the phrase 'avec des Lunettes,' literally 'with some glasses/lenses'), used in the context of observing features on the sun, could be ambiguous in the 17th century (referring to spectacles or telescopes). The translation 'their Tellescopes' explicitly clarifies that the instrument is an astronomical telescope. The addition of 'their' also specifies possession, implicitly referring to the astronomers or observers.

The French 'des Lunettes mesme' (even the optical instruments themselves), which are credited with providing 'la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects' (knowledge of so many new objects), is translated as 'our Tellescopes.' This choice explicitly identifies these crucial instruments as astronomical telescopes and, through 'our,' connects their importance to the collective human endeavor of scientific discovery, a nuance not directly present in 'des Lunettes mesme'.

The French 'une infinité de bizareries' (an infinity of oddities/irregularities) describes the apparently complex and irregular motions of planets as seen from Earth. The translation 'extravagant fancies' explicitly interprets these observed irregularities not just as oddities but as illusions or products of a flawed perspective ('fancies'). While the source text later explains these are due to viewpoint, the word 'fancies' front-loads this interpretation, making the illusory nature of the 'bizareries' immediately explicit.

The French text describes various dynamic behaviors of sunspots: 'tantost elles disparoissent toutes' (sometimes they all disappear), 'quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble' (sometimes several group together), 'quelquefois elles se separent' (sometimes they separate). The English translation re-casts part of this description by explicitly adding and emphasizing a durational aspect: 'sometimes they continue a great while' (implying persistence in a state) and 'sometimes they disappear as long' (specifying a length of time for their absence). This spells out temporal characteristics of the sunspots' states that were only implicit or inferable from the original's focus on the events of change themselves.

chunks.source_manual: <P063>J'avoüe que je m'estois trompé, répondis-je, je ne songeois qu'à la situation où est le Soleil,& non à l'effet de sa lumiere; mais vous qui me redressez si à propos, vous voulez bien que je vous dise que vous vous estes trompée aussi; les Habitans du Soleil ne le verroient seulement pas. Ou ils ne pourroient soûtenir la force de sa lumiere, ou ils ne la pourroient recevoir, faute d'en estre à quelque distance, & tout bien considéré, le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles; encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour estre habité; mais voulez-vous que nous poursuivions nostre Voyage des Mondes? Nous sommes arrivéz au centre qui est toûjours le lieu le plus bas dans tout ce qui est rond, il faudroit presentement retourner sur nos pas, & remonter. Nous retrouverons Mercure, Venus, la Terre, la Lune, toutes Planetes que nous avons visitées. Ensuite c'est Mars qui se presente. Mars n'a rien de curieux que je sçache, ses jours ne sont pas d'une heure entiere plus longs que les nostres; ses années valent deux de nos années. Il est plus petit que la Terre, il voit le Soleil un peu moins grand & moins vif que nous ne le voyons; enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arreste. Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter avec ses quatre Lunes ou <RW>Satellites</RW>! Ce sont quatre petites Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, comme nostre Lune tourne autour de nous. Mais, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, pourquoy y a-t-il des Planetes qui tournent autour d'autres Planetes qui ne valent pas mieux qu'elles? Serieusement il me paroîtroit plus regulier & plus uniforme que toutes les Planetes, grandes & petites, n'eussent que le mesme mouvement autour du Soleil!</P063>
chunks.target_manual: <P052>I own said I, my mistake; I was thinking of the Situation of the Sun, and not of the effect of its Light: I thank you for your correction, but must take the boldness to tell you, that you are in an errour, as well as my self; for were there Inhabitants in the Sun, they would not see at all, either they could not bear the strength of its light, or for want of a due distance, they could not receive it; so that things well consider'd, all the People there must be stark blind, which is another reason why the Sun cannot be inhabited; but let us pursue our Voyage. We are now arriv'd at the Centre, which is always the bottom, or lowest place of what is round; if we go on, we must ascend; we shall find Mercury, Venus, the Earth, the Moon, all the Planets we have already visited; the next is Mars: Mars hath nothing curious that I know of, his Day is not quite an hour longer than ours, but his Year is twice as much as our Year; he is a little less than the Earth; and the Sun seems not altogether so large and so bright to him, as it appears to us? but let us leave Mars, he is not worth our stay: But what a pretty thing is Jupiter, with his four Moons, <UP>or Yeomen of the Guard</UP>; they are four little Planets that turn round him, as our Moon turns round us. But why, says she, interrupting me, must there be Planets to turn round other Planets, that are no better than themselves? I should think it would be more regular and uniform, that all the Planets, little and great, without any distinction, should have one and the same motion round the Sun.</P052>
