and spread from their wings another day.
explanations: The French "tout cela est d'un grand ordre" (all this is of a great order) states a characteristic of the universe. The English "all is contriv'd in such great order" makes explicit the idea of active design or intentional arrangement by using "contriv'd," implying an agent (Nature) has deliberately planned things, a concept only implied by the state of order in the French.

The French "la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins" (Nature had in view/foresaw the needs) implies Nature's consideration. The English "Nature took time to consider the necessities" expands on this by explicitly detailing the *process* ("took time") and active nature ("to consider") of this foresight, making Nature's deliberation more pronounced.

The translator adds the parenthetical clause "(as short as they are)" when describing why the nights are considered a blessing. While the shortness of the nights is mentioned earlier in the French sentence ("dont les nuits sont fort courtes"), its re-iteration here explicitly spells out the connection between this characteristic and the appreciation of the nights, a link that was less syntactically direct in the source.

The French "Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars... n'a point de Lune" (But wait, it seems to me that Mars... has no Moon) expresses the Marquise's realization as an observation. The English translation reframes this by first posing a direct question from her ("But pray, why has not Mars a Moon too?") before stating the observation. This makes her reasoning process and her interrogative stance more explicit.

The French "Vous ne sçauriez nier que..." (You could not deny that...) presents the philosopher's point as an assertion the Marquise is expected to affirm. The English translation "What think you, Madam, is it not very pleasant..." changes this into direct questions, explicitly soliciting the Marquise's personal opinion and reaction, thereby making the dialogic engagement more overt and altering the philosopher's rhetorical approach.

The French "faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques" (make magnificent illuminations without any art/artifice) describes naturally occurring splendid lights. The English translation replaces this description with a simile, "like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night," which adds a specific and culturally resonant example ("at a Birth day night") for a contemporary English audience. This concretizes "magnificent illuminations" by providing a familiar frame of reference, thus adding clarifying information.

The French "& vont répandre un nouveau jour?" (and go to spread a new day/light?) describes the birds spreading light. The English "and spread from their wings another day" makes this more concrete by explicitly adding the detail "from their wings" as the means by which the birds spread light. This anatomical or functional detail is not stated in the source text.

chunks.source_manual: <P079>Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oyseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse esté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fust point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vrayment, repliquay-je, si <LS><IIM>vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites</IIM></LS>, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de mesme pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous estions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos testes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroist une habitation trop irreguliere. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'estoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échapées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez miserables. Il leur donne de la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.</P079>
chunks.target_manual: <P061>I am not at all contented, says she, with your Rocks, or your Birds; 'tis a pretty fancy indeed, but 'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars, since Nature hath given so many to Saturn, and Jupiter; and if all the other Worlds that are distant from the Sun, have Moons, why should Mars only be excepted? Ah, Madam, said I, when you are a little more dip'd in Philosophy, you will find exceptions in the very best Systemes; there are always some things that agree extream well, but then there are others that do not accord at all; those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end: We will do so by Mars, if you please, and say no more of him; but return to Saturn. What do you think of his great Ring, in the form of a semy Circle, that reaches from one end of the Horizon to the other, which reflecting the light of the Sun, performs the office of a continual Moon. And must we not inhabit this Ring too, says she? I confess, said I, in the humour I am in, I could almost send Colonies every where; and yet I can't well plant any there, it seems so irregular an habitation; but for the five little Moons, they cannot chuse but be inhabited; tho' some think this Ring is a Circle of Moons, which follow close to one another, and have one equal Motion; and that the five little Moons fell out of this Circle; how many Worlds are there then in the <UP>Vortex of Saturn</UP>? But let it be how it will, the People in Saturn live very miserably: 'Tis true, this Ring gives light to 'em, but it must be a very poor one, when the Sun seems to 'em but a little pale Star, whose light and heat cannot but be very weak at so great a distance; they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys.</P061>
source_segments: c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes.
ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout.
nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil
à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment
qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible
si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.
target_segments: 'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars,
those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end:
and say no more of him; but return to Saturn.
reflecting the light of the Sun
I could almost send Colonies every where
it must be a very poor one
whose light and heat cannot but be very weak at so great a distance
they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys.
explanations: The French states a general principle ('Moons are needed') based on Nature's provision for Jupiter and Saturn. The English translation makes this principle immediately and explicitly apply to Mars ('Moons in Mars') within the same clause, clarifying the specific target of the Marquise's reasoning which is only fully articulated in her next sentence in the source text.

The French 'si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout' (if one despairs of being able to overcome it) indicates stopping due to frustration with a specific intractable problem. The English 'if ever you intend to make an end' explicitly adds the broader pragmatic motivation of needing to complete the overall system or argument, a practical reason for abandoning the problem that was only implied in the source.

The French text proposes to stop discussing Mars ('& ne parlons point de luy' - and let's not speak of him). The English translation adds 'but return to Saturn,' explicitly stating the next topic of conversation and guiding the dialogue, a transition that is implied by the subsequent discussion in the source but not explicitly stated at this juncture.

The French 'renvoyant la lumiere' (sending back/returning the light) is a general description of the action. The English 'reflecting the light' uses a more specific optical and scientific term, explicitly stating the mechanism by which the ring would return sunlight. This adds a layer of scientific precision, aligning with the popular science nature of the work.

The French 'à en envoyer par tout' (to send [them/inhabitants] everywhere) is general about who or what would be sent to populate other worlds. The English translation 'send Colonies every where' explicitly specifies that 'Colonies' (organized groups of settlers) would be sent, adding a concrete image and a layer of meaning related to deliberate settlement not explicitly present in the more general French phrasing.

The French 'quelle lumiere' (what light!) is a rhetorical exclamation by the philosopher, implying that the light Saturn receives from its ring (reflecting sunlight) would be poor or insufficient. The English translation 'it must be a very poor one' makes this implied negative assessment of the light's quality explicit and declarative.

The French states that the Sun, for Saturnians, has 'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible' (a very faint brightness and heat). The English translation 'whose light and heat cannot but be very weak at so great a distance' explicitly re-inserts the reason ('at so great a distance') for this weakness within the same clause. While Saturn's distance was mentioned earlier in the paragraph in French, its re-iteration here directly links cause and effect more explicitly than the source text does in this specific phrase.

The French describes a hypothetical scenario where Saturnians, if placed in Earth's coldest regions like Greenland, would 'suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud' (sweat profusely and expire from heat), thereby implying Saturn's extreme coldness relative to Earth. The English translation re-writes this by making the relative temperature difference explicit through the direct comparative statement 'Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet.' This uses the vivid term 'Bagnio' (a hot bathhouse) to emphasize the contrast, changing the indirect implication into a direct assertion. The introduction 'they say' also alters the rhetorical style, framing it as a commonly understood comparison rather than the philosopher's immediate hypothetical.

chunks.source_manual: <P080>Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, au lieu que tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, repliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extremitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.</P080> <P081>Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde estoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne sçavent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique <IIM>trop badin & trop folâtre</IIM>. <NCE></NCE>.</P081>
chunks.target_manual: <P062>You give me, says she, such an Idea of Saturn, that makes me shake with cold, and that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver. It cannot be otherwise, I reply'd, for the two Worlds, which are the extremities of this great Vortex, must be opposite in all things. They must then, says she, be very wise in Saturn, for you told me they were all Fools in Mercury. If they are not wise, said I, yet they have all the appearances of being very Flegmatick: They are People that know not what 'tis to laugh, they take a days time to answer the least question you can ask 'em; and are so very grave, that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him <NCE>a merry Andrew</NCE>.</P062>
target_segments: puts me into a feaver
a merry Andrew
explanations: The French "m'échauffiez" (you were warming/exciting me) implies an increase in bodily heat or emotional agitation due to the description of Mercury. The English "puts me into a feaver" explicitates this by specifying a particular, intense, and potentially discomfiting state of being overheated and agitated (a 'fever'), which is a more specific condition than the general sense of being 'warmed' or 'excited' implied by the French verb. This re-writing makes the Marquise's reaction more vivid and physiologically specific.

The French adjectives "trop badin & trop folâtre" (too playful/joking and too frolicsome/mischievous) describe how the Saturnians would perceive Cato of Utica's character. The English translation "a merry Andrew" re-writes this by making explicit a specific cultural archetype – that of a buffoon or clown. This changes the description from general qualities of excessive lightheartedness to a concrete noun phrase representing a type of person known for foolish antics, thereby making the Saturnians' negative judgment more specific and extreme than conveyed by the original adjectives.

chunks.source_manual: <P082>Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lens. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nostre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extremitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractere fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différens. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'estre icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.</P082>
chunks.target_manual: <P063>It is odd to consider, says she, that the Inhabitants of Mercury are all life, and the Inhabitants of Saturn quite contrary; but among us, some are brisk, and some are dull; it is, I suppose, because our Earth is plac'd in the middle of the other Worlds, and so we participate of both extreams, there is no fix'd or determin'd Character; some are made like the Inhabitants of Mercury, some like those of Saturn; we are a mixture of the several kinds that are found in the rest of the Planets. Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds; we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.</P063>
source_segments: il est assez commode d'estre icy
target_segments: all life
quite contrary
of both extreams
we need not travel
explanations: The French 'vifs' (lively), used to describe the essential nature of Mercurians, is translated as 'all life'. This translation makes the extreme and defining nature of this characteristic explicit. While 'vifs' implies strong vivacity, 'all life' elevates this to an almost quintessential state, thereby emphasizing the pure, unmixed nature of this trait in Mercurians, which is implied in Fontenelle's characterization of planetary inhabitants.

The French 'lens' (slow) describes Saturn's inhabitants, contrasting with Mercury's 'vifs.' Instead of a direct equivalent like 'slow' or 'dull' (which the translator uses for humans later: 'some are dull'), the translation 'quite contrary' explicitly spells out the oppositional relationship to Mercury's inhabitants being 'all life.' This makes the stark polarity between the two planetary types more explicit than the simple juxtaposition of 'vifs' and 'lens' in the source.

The French 'des extremitez' (of the extremes), referring to the characteristics of different planetary inhabitants, is translated as 'of both extreams'. The addition of 'both' makes explicit that 'extremitez' refers specifically to the two previously mentioned contrasting characteristics (the vivacity of Mercury's inhabitants and the slowness of Saturn's), clarifying the scope and direct referents of 'the extremes'.

The French phrase 'il est assez commode d'estre icy' (it is quite convenient to be here) states a general benefit. The target text makes the practical implication of this convenience explicit by stating 'we need not travel'. This spells out a specific advantage (not needing to travel) that is implied by the convenience of being on Earth and seeing an epitome of all other worlds there.

chunks.source_manual: <P083>Du moins, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nostre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grace à la Nature d'estre Homme, & non pas Beste, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moy je veux luy rendre grace d'estre sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grace d'estre jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & <UP></UP> belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vostre Tourbillon, ou de la temperature de vostre Pays.</P083>
chunks.target_manual: <P064>I am sure, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, we have one great convenience in the situation of our World; it is not so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Jupiter or Saturn; and our Country is so justly plac'd, that we have no excess either of Heat or Cold. I have heard of a Philosopher, who gave thanks to Nature that he was born a Man, and not a Beast, a Greek, and not a Barbarian; and for my part, I render thanks that I am seated in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in one of the most temperate Regions of that Planet. You have more reason, said I, to give thanks that you are Young, and not Old; that you are Young and Handsome, and not Young and Ugly; that you are Young, Handsome, and an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, <UP>and a Spaniard</UP>, or an Italian; these are other guess Subjects for your thanks, than the Situation of your Vortex, or the Temperature of your Countrey.</P064>
target_segments: our Country
You have more reason
an English Woman
a Spaniard, or an Italian
explanations: The original French 'un endroit de la Terre' (a place on Earth) is a general term for a temperate location. The translation 'our Country' makes this specific, explicitly linking the ideal temperate location to the assumed nation of the English reader (i.e., England). This is Explicitation as Re-writing because the translator specifies the general 'place' as the reader's own nation, thereby making an implied national framing or preference explicit for the target audience.

The French 'Si vous m'en croyez' (If you believe me/take my advice) introduces a series of reasons for gratitude as suggestions. The translation 'You have more reason' explicitly asserts that these forthcoming reasons are of greater significance or validity than those previously mentioned by the Countess. The source text implies these are strong, perhaps superior, reasons, but the target text spells out this comparative hierarchy ('more reason') explicitly, clarifying the unstated relationship regarding the weight of these arguments.

The source text's 'Françoise' (French woman) explicitly names the nationality held up as an ideal within the original French cultural context, appealing to a French reader's national pride. The translation to 'an English Woman' is a re-writing that makes explicit the equivalent high-value nationality for the English target audience. The implicit rhetorical strategy of invoking national preference is thus re-instantiated and made explicit within the new cultural framework of Protestant England, adapting the text for its new readers.

The French 'Italienne' (Italian woman) is used as the sole contrasting example of a less desirable nationality. The translation expands this to 'a Spaniard, or an Italian.' The addition of 'a Spaniard' is an explicitation that broadens the scope of this negative comparison. While the source text's single example 'Italienne' might implicitly represent a category of 'less preferred foreignness' (e.g., Catholic, Southern European from a French perspective), the translator makes this category more explicit and culturally specific for the English Protestant audience by adding 'Spaniard'—Spain being a major Catholic power and historical adversary. This expansion spells out a wider range of contrasting 'other' nationalities relevant to the target culture.

chunks.source_manual: <P084>Mon Dieu! repliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a esté donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considerables, un goust qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, repliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles Fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez veu jusqu'icy.</P084>
chunks.target_manual: <P065>Pray Sir, says she, let me give thanks for all things, to the very Vortex in which I am planted: Our proportion of Happiness is so very small, that we should lose none, but improve continually what we have, and be grateful for every thing, tho' never so common or inconsiderable. If nothing but exquisite pleasure will serve us, we must wait a long time, and be sure to pay too dear for it at last. I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships. I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer. I will engage for it till to morrow, I reply'd, for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.</P065>
source_segments: mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux
target_segments: Pray Sir
be sure to pay too dear for it at last
an humble Servant of your Ladyships
while it diverts innocently, but no longer
explanations: The French "Mon Dieu!" is a general exclamation of surprise or emphasis. The English "Pray Sir" recasts this as a direct address to the philosopher ("Sir"), explicitly identifying him as the recipient of the Marquise's utterance. While the philosopher is the established interlocutor, "Mon Dieu!" could be uttered more generally, whereas "Pray Sir" makes the interpersonal direction explicit within the exclamation itself, altering its character from a general interjection to a specific address.

The French "on les payeroit bien" implies a high cost ("one would pay dearly for them"). The English translation "be sure to pay too dear for it at last" explicitates and intensifies this by: 1) specifying the cost as excessive ("too dear" rather than just "dearly" or "well"), and 2) adding a temporal dimension ("at last") which makes explicit the eventual, unfavorable realization of this high cost. This expansion clarifies the negative consequences only implied by "bien" in this context.

The French "de moy" (of me) is a simple, direct self-reference by the philosopher. The English translation expands this into "an humble Servant of your Ladyships," which makes explicit a highly formal and deferential social relationship between the philosopher (as a commoner) and the Marquise (as nobility). This spells out a power dynamic and social posture using conventional period-specific honorifics, significantly altering the tone from the original's simplicity.

The Marquise's original French is a direct request: "mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux" (but ensure that Philosophy always provides me with new pleasures). The English translation transforms this. Her line, "I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer," recasts her desire for novelty into a conditional acceptance of philosophy. The specific segment "while it diverts innocently, but no longer" introduces conditions of "innocence" and a temporal limitation if this condition isn't met. These conditions, not present in the French, explicitly add a layer of societal expectation concerning the appropriate nature and limits of a noblewoman's engagement with intellectual pursuits in that era, thus re-writing her open-ended request into a socially constrained acceptance.

chunks.source_manual: <P085>CINQUIEME SOIR.</P085>
chunks.target_manual: <P066>The Fifth Evening.</P066>

chunks.source_manual: <P086><UP></UP>. La <IIM>Marquise</IIM> sentit une vraye impatience de sçavoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes, me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-estre, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sçauroient estre moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuës, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est rien par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumiere, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM> <UP></UP>; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumiere qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM>, eust cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.</P086>
chunks.target_manual: <P067>THE <IIM>Countess</IIM> was very impatient to know what would become of the fix'd Stars; are they inhabited, says she, as the Planets are, or are they not inhabited? What shall we do with 'em? You may soon guess, said I; the fix'd Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than fifty millions of leagues; nay, if you anger an Astronomer, he will set 'em further. The distance from the Sun to the farthest Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance from the Sun, or from the Earth, to the fix'd Stars, it is almost beyond Arithmetick. You see their light is bright and shining, and did they receive it from the Sun, it must needs be very weak after a passage of <NCE>fifty millions of leagues</NCE>; then judge how much it is wasted by reflection; for it comes back again as far to us; so that forwards and backwards, here are <NCE>an hundred millions of leagues</NCE> for it to pass; and it is impossible it should be so clear and strong as the light of a fix'd Star, which cannot but proceed from it self; so that in a word, all the fix'd Stars are so many Suns.</P067>
source_segments: on ne prend pas la peine de la compter.
elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance.
fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuës,
Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes,
target_segments: it is almost beyond Arithmetick.
for it comes back again as far to us;
so that forwards and backwards, here are an hundred millions of leagues for it to pass;
which cannot but proceed from it self;
explanations: The French phrase "on ne prend pas la peine de la compter" (one doesn't bother to count/calculate it) implies that the task is either too laborious or the result too vast to be meaningful in the context of the conversation. The English translation "it is almost beyond Arithmetick" explicitly states the reason for not bothering: the sheer magnitude of the distance makes it practically incalculable or incomprehensible in numerical terms, thus adding a specific clarification for why the counting is omitted.

The French "elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance" (they would send it back to us at this same distance) describes the result of light's reflection. The English translation "for it comes back again as far to us;" adds an explanatory layer. The conjunction "for" explicitly provides a reason, and the phrase "comes back again" makes the process of the light's return journey more explicit, clarifying that "cette mesme distance" refers to the distance of the return path, thus spelling out the mechanics of reflection more directly than the original's implication.

The French phrase "fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuës" (and travelled/covered twice fifty million leagues) concisely states the total distance light would travel if reflected. The English translation "so that forwards and backwards, here are an hundred millions of leagues for it to pass;" explicitly breaks down this concept by: 1) spelling out the reason for the doubling ("forwards and backwards"), which was implied by the context of reflection and return journey, and 2) performing the multiplication ("an hundred millions of leagues"), thereby expanding the condensed mathematical expression for greater clarity.

The French "Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes" (So there they are, luminous by themselves) states a conclusion about the stars' inherent luminosity. The English translation, referring to the light of a fixed star, "which cannot but proceed from it self;" makes the logical deduction from the preceding argument more explicit. Instead of just stating the property of the stars (being luminous), it explains the origin of their light ("proceed from it self") as a necessary consequence ("cannot but") of the previously established impossibility of it being reflected light, thus spelling out the unstated inferential step for the reader.

chunks.source_manual: <P087>Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nostre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Nostre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé. <UP></UP>.</P087>
chunks.target_manual: <P068>I perceive, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, where you would carry me; you are going to tell me, that if the fix'd Stars are so many Suns, and our Sun the centre of a Vortex that turns round him, why may not every fix'd Star be the centre of a Vortex that turns round the fix'd Star? Our Sun enlightens the Planets; why may not every fix'd Star have Planets to which they give light? You have said it, <UP>I reply'd, and I will not contradict you</UP>.</P068>
source_segments: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils
un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle
Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé..
target_segments: if the fix'd Stars are so many Suns
a Vortex that turns round the fix'd Star
have Planets
You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you.
explanations: The translator introduces 'if', making explicit the hypothetical nature of the statement ('the fix'd Stars are so many Suns') as a premise in the argument the Marquise anticipates. The French original presents this more as a direct assertion ('Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils') that she expects the philosopher to make, with its conditional status within his potential argument being more implicit.

The French phrase 'qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle' (which will have a movement around it) describes motion in general terms. The English translation 'that turns round the fix'd Star' makes explicit the specific rotational nature of this movement. This rotational quality is strongly implied in the source by the term 'Tourbillon' (Vortex) and the directional 'autour d'elle' (around it), but the French verb 'aura un mouvement' (will have a movement) does not specify the type of motion as explicitly as 'turns round'.

The French pronoun 'en' in 'n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi' (will it not also have some) anaphorically refers to 'Planetes' (Planets) from the preceding clause. The English translation renders this part as 'have Planets' (within the larger phrase 'why may not every fix'd Star have Planets'), explicitly restating the noun 'Planets' instead of using a pronoun. This expands the condensed pronominal reference, making the object fully explicit.

The translator replaces the philosopher's learned classical allusion ('Je n'ay à vous répondre... que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé..' meaning 'I have only to answer you... what Phaedra answered Oenone, 'It is you who named him/it..'') with a direct and unambiguous statement of agreement: 'You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you.' The original allusion implicitly conveys agreement, requiring cultural knowledge from the reader. The translation makes this agreement fully explicit, altering Fontenelle's rhetorical style and the intended reader experience by removing the reliance on such knowledge.

chunks.source_manual: <P088>Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sçais plus où je suis, <RW>je ne suis plus rien</RW>. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-estre aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes? Tout cet espace immense qui comprend nostre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes? <UP></UP>. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moy, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le Ciel n'estoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles estoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte <UP></UP>, en la partageant en mille & mille <RW>Tourbillons</RW>, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & asseurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous costez les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde.<UP></UP>.</P088>
chunks.target_manual: <P069>You have made the Universe so large, says she, that I know not where I am, or what will become of me; what is it all to be divided into heaps confusedly, one among another? Is every Star the centre of a Vortex, as big as ours? Is that vast space which comprehends our Sun and Planets, but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? and are there as many such spaces, as there are fix'd Stars? <UP>I protest it is dreadful. Dreadful, Madam, said I</UP>; I think it very pleasant, when the Heavens were a little blue Arch, stuck with Stars; methought the Universe was too strait and close, I was almost stifled for want of Air; but now it is enlarg'd in heigth and breadth, and a thousand and a thousand Vortex's taken in; I begin to breath with more freedom, and think the Universe to be incomparably <UP>more magnificent than it was before</UP>. Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness, and nothing can be so glorious, as to see such a prodigious number of Vortex's, whose several centres are possess'd by a particular Sun, which makes the Planets turn round it. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of these innumerable Vortex's, see on all sides these luminous centres of the Vortex, with which they are encompass'd; but perhaps they do not see the Planets, who receiving but a faint light from their Sun, cannot send it beyond their own World.</P069>
source_segments: Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante.
Et moy, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise.
La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses
mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes
target_segments: or what will become of me
inconsiderable part
I protest it is dreadful.
Dreadful, Madam, said I;
a little blue Arch
I was almost stifled for want of Air
in heigth and breadth
incomparably more magnificent than it was before
Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness,
a particular Sun
but perhaps they do not see the Planets
explanations: The French "je ne suis plus rien" (I am nothing anymore) expresses an abstract existential diminishment. The English "or what will become of me" makes an implied personal consequence of this feeling (concern for one's future and fate) explicit, tailoring the Marquise's anxiety to be more direct and perhaps more relatable to the target audience.

The French "petite parcelle" (small part/particle) primarily describes size. The English "inconsiderable part" makes the implied evaluative judgment—that such a small part is trivial or insignificant in the larger context—explicit.

The French "Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante" lists three internal states (that confuses me, troubles me, frightens me). The English "I protest it is dreadful" makes the Marquise's outward expression of strong negative reaction explicit through the performative "I protest," in addition to summarizing the feeling as "dreadful."

The French text has the philosopher responding ("Et moy, répondis-je") without an explicit term of address to the Marquise in this specific utterance. The English translation adds "Madam" ("Dreadful, Madam, said I;"), making the addressee explicit and adhering to conventions of polite dialogue in English of the period.

The French "cette voûte bleuë" (this blue vault) is rendered as "a little blue Arch." The addition of "little" explicitly foregrounds the limited and small perception of the old model of the universe, a quality that is implied by contrast with the vast new model being introduced, but not directly stated in the French description of the vault itself.

The French "je m'y sentois comme oppressé" (I felt as if oppressed there) describes a general feeling. The English "I was almost stifled for want of Air" makes the specific physical sensation and implied cause of this oppression (suffocation due to lack of space/air in a confined universe) explicit, adding a vivid, concrete detail.

The French "plus d'étenduë & de profondeur" (more extent and depth) refers to general spatial increase. The English "in heigth and breadth" makes the specific dimensions of this expansion explicit by using common English terms for two-dimensional enlargement.

The French "toute une autre magnificence" (a completely different magnificence) implies a comparison to a previous state or understanding. The English "incomparably more magnificent than it was before" makes this comparative baseline ("than it was before") explicit, clearly stating the point of reference for the change in perceived magnificence.

The French states Nature "n'a rien épargné en le produisant" (spared nothing in producing it) and separately that "elle a fait une profusion des richesses" (she made a profusion of riches). The English "Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness," explicitly links these concepts by using "even to profuseness" to qualify the extent of "sparing no cost." Furthermore, "cost" makes explicit a specific, albeit metaphorical, category of what was not spared, where the French "rien" (nothing) is more general.

The French "un Soleil" (a Sun), in the context of "dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil" (whose middle is occupied by a Sun), where "le milieu" refers distributively to the center of each of numerous vortices, implies a distinct sun for each. The English "a particular Sun" makes this individuality and specificity of each sun for its respective vortex explicit.

The French idiom "ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes" strongly implies they do not or cannot see them (lit. 'they take care not to see them', meaning they are far from seeing/by no means see them). The English "but perhaps they do not see the Planets" explicitly introduces an element of conjecture with "perhaps," thereby making the speculative nature of this astronomical point explicit to the reader, possibly also to soften the assertion in a context of evolving scientific understanding.

chunks.source_manual: <P089>Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de nostre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; apres eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les apperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous estes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis? <IIM>Nous mesmes, à qui la mesme expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sçauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes</IIM>. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. <IIM>Asseurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoist pas les Tourbillons</IIM>. <UP></UP>. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondray: Ah! si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas sceu, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'estoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fust dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?) <UP></UP> mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eust esté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eust pas pû conquerir. A plus forte raison luy eust-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eust connus en ce temps-là; c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon vostre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.</P089>
chunks.target_manual: <P070>You present me with a kind of Perspective of so vast a length, that no Eye can reach to the end of it: I plainly see the Inhabitants of the Earth, and you have made me discover those that dwell in the Moon, and in other Planets of our Vortex; but these indeed I do not see so clearly as those of the Earth; after these, we come to the Inhabitants of the Planets which are in other Vortex's, but they are sunk into so great a depth, that tho' I do all I can to see them, yet <UP>I must confess</UP> I can hardly perceive 'em; by the expression you use in speaking of 'em, they seem to be almost annihilated; you ought then to call 'em the Inhabitants of one of those innumerable Vortex's: We our selves, for whom the same expression serves, must confess, that we scarce know where we are, in the midst of so many Worlds; for my own part, I begin to see the Earth so fearfully little, that I believe from henceforth, I shall never be concern'd at all for any thing: That we so eagerly desire to make our selves great, that we are always designing, always troubling and harassing our selves, is certainly because we are ignorant what these Vortex's are; but now I hope my new lights will in part justifie my laziness, and when any one reproaches me with my carelessness, I will answer, Ah did you but know what the fix'd Stars are! It was not fit, said I, that Alexander should know what they were; for a certain Author who maintains that the Moon is inhabited, very gravely tells us, that Aristotle, (from whom no truth could be long conceal'd) must necessarily be of an opinion, back'd with so much reason; but yet he would never acquaint Alexander with the secret, fearing he might run mad with despair, when he knew there was another World, which he could not conquer; with much more reason then was this mystery of Vortex's, and fix'd Stars kept secret in Alexander's time; for tho' they had been known in those days, yet a Man would have been a great Fool, to have said any thing of 'em to Alexander; it had been but an ill way of making his court to that ambitious Prince; for my part, I that know 'em, am not a little troubled to find my self not one jot the wiser for all the knowledge I have of 'em; the most they can do, according to your way of reasoning, is but to cure People of their ambition, and their unquiet restless humour, which are diseases I am not at all troubled with; I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful; that's my distemper, and I am confident, the Vortex's can never cure it: what if the other Worlds render ours so very little? they cannot spoil fine Eyes, or a pretty Mouth; their value is still the same, in spite of all the Worlds that can possibly exist.</P070>
source_segments: si on se donne tant de peine
ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres
(comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?)
c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour
Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau
target_segments: those that dwell in the Moon
always troubling and harassing our selves
my new lights will in part justifie my laziness
(from whom no truth could be long conceal'd)
he might run mad with despair
a Man would have been a great Fool
that ambitious Prince
not one jot the wiser
their unquiet restless humour
I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful
explanations: The French 'ceux de la Lune' (those of the Moon), following a mention of 'Habitans' (Inhabitants), implies inhabitants. The English 'those that dwell in the Moon' explicitly adds the verb 'dwell in,' spelling out the unstated action or relationship of these beings to the Moon.

The French 'si on se donne tant de peine' (if one takes so much trouble/pains) is a general expression of effort. The English 'always troubling and harassing our selves' explicitly interprets this 'peine' as a specific kind of negative, self-inflicted psychological agitation, adding clarifying information about the nature of the effort that was only one possible implication of the original.

The French 'ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres' (my laziness benefits from my new insights) indicates a general advantage. The English 'my new lights will in part justifie my laziness' makes explicit the *mechanism* of this benefit, interpreting 'profiter de' (to benefit from) as finding 'justification,' thereby spelling out how laziness benefits.

The French rhetorical question '(comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?)' (how could a truth have escaped Aristotle?) strongly implies his comprehensive knowledge. The English translation '(from whom no truth could be long conceal'd)' converts this implication into a direct, explicit declarative statement about Aristotle's capacity to know.

The French 'qui eust esté au despoir' (who would have been in despair) describes a state of despair. The English 'he might run mad with despair' explicitly adds 'run mad with,' significantly intensifying the state by suggesting a potential descent into madness, thereby adding clarifying information about the severity or potential outcome of the despair not literally present in the original.

The French 'c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour' (it would have been to court him very badly/poorly) describes the quality or outcome of an action. The English 'a Man would have been a great Fool' shifts to an explicit judgment on the person performing such an action, spelling out an implied negative assessment of the agent's prudence or intelligence.

The French pronoun 'luy' (to him), in the context of 'de luy en parler' (to speak to him of it), refers to Alexander. The English translation refers to Alexander as 'that ambitious Prince' in a related clause. This makes the reference explicit by name (contextually, as Alexander is the subject) and adds the descriptive 'ambitious Prince,' spelling out his key characteristic relevant to the situation, which was implied by the broader anecdote.

The French 'de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité' (not being able to draw utility/benefit) expresses a general lack of benefit. The English 'not one jot the wiser' makes this lack of utility more specific by explicitly defining it as a failure to gain wisdom or practical insight, thus clarifying the particular type of 'utilité' the speaker feels is missing.

The French 'l'inquietude' translates to anxiety, worry, or restlessness. The English 'their unquiet restless humour' expands on this by adding 'humour,' explicitly linking the state to the contemporary (to the translation) psychophysiological theory of humours. This adds a specific conceptual framework that was not explicit in the original term.

The French 'Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau' (a little weakness for what is beautiful) is a relatively understated admission. The English 'I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful' makes this more explicit by framing the weakness as a confessed fault ('I am guilty of') and by intensifying 'foiblesse pour' to the stronger, more emotionally specific 'to be in love with,' thus spelling out both a moral stance and a deeper emotional state that were understated or only implied in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P090>C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez-moy franchement, vostre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-mesme comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sçauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien-tost aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De mesme accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-mesme il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez-vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroist, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroist point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune estoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nostre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous estes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grace. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nostre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.</P090> <P091>Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nostre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nostre, qui n'y paroist que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est à dire, des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, <NCP>nostre Terre, par exemple</NCP>, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont les uniques de leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?</P091>
chunks.target_manual: <P071>This Love, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, smiling, is a strange thing; let the World go how 'twill, 'tis never in danger; there is no System can do it any harm. But tell me freely, is your System true? Pray conceal nothing from me; I will keep your secret very faithfully; it seems to have for its foundation, but a slight probability; which is, that if a fix'd Star be in it self a luminous Body, like the Sun, then by consequence, it must as the Sun is, be the Centre and Soul of a World; and have its Planets turning round about it: But is there an absolute necessity it must be so? Madam, said I, since we are in the humour of mingling amorous Follies with our most serious Discourses, I must tell you, that in Love and the Mathematicks People reason alike: Allow never so little to a Lover, yet presently after you must grant him more; nay more and more, which will at last go a great way: In like manner, grant but a Mathematician one little Principle, he immediately draws a consequence from it, to which you must necessarily assent; and from this consequence another, till he leads you so far (whether you will or no) that you have much ado to believe him. These two sorts of People, Lovers and Mathematicians, will always take more than you give 'em. You grant that when two things are like one another in all those things that appear to you, it is possible they may be like one another in those things that are not visible, if you have not some good reason to believe otherwise: Now this way of arguing have I made use of. The Moon, say I, is inhabited, because she is like the Earth; and the other Planets are inhabited, because they are like the Moon; I find the fix'd Stars to be like our Sun, therefore I attribute to them what is proper to that: You are now gone too far to be able to retreat, therefore you must go forward with a good grace. But, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, if you build upon this resemblance or likeness which is between our Sun and the fix'd Stars, then, to the People of another great Vortex, our Sun must appear no bigger than a small fix'd Star, and can be seen only when 'tis Night with them. <UP>Without doubt</UP>, Madam, said I, it must be so: Our Sun is much nearer to us, than the Suns of other Vortex's, and therefore its Light makes a much greater impression on our Eyes, than theirs do: We see nothing but the light of our own Sun, and when we see that, it darkens and hinders us from seeing any other light: but in another great Vortex, there is another Sun, which rules and governs, and, in its turn, extinguisheth the light of our Sun, which is never seen there, but in the Night, with the rest of the other Suns, that is the fix'd Stars; with them our Sun is fastned to the great arched roof of Heaven, where it makes a part of some Bear or Bull: For the Planets which turn round about it, <NCP>(our Earth for Example)</NCP> as they are not seen at so vast a distance, so no body doth so much as dream of 'em: All the Suns then are Day Suns in their own Vortex's, but Night Suns in other Vortex's: In his own World or Sphere every Sun is single, and there is but one to be seen; but every where else, they serve only to make a number. May not the Worlds, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, notwithstanding this great resemblance between 'em, differ in a thousand other things; for tho' they may be alike in one particular, they may differ infinitely in others.</P071>

explanations: The French 'il se sauve de tout' (love survives everything / is never in danger [in the context of the translation's latter part]) is rendered as ''tis never in danger'. The translator prefaces this with the clause 'let the World go how 'twill,' which adds clarifying information about the circumstances under which love is never in danger. This explicitation specifies the general 'tout' (everything) by framing it as general worldly vicissitudes, which was only implied in the source.

The French states that a fixed star 'il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde' (must be like the Sun, the centre & the soul of a World). The English translation 'it must as the Sun is, be the Centre and Soul of a World' explicitly adds 'as the Sun is', clarifying *in what way* the star must be the centre and soul – by directly stating the comparison to the Sun's role, a detail implied by 'comme le Soleil' but made more emphatic and structurally explicit here.

The French 'les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour.' (mathematical reasonings are made like Love/are like Love) is more abstract. The English 'that in Love and the Mathematicks People reason alike:' explicitates the comparison by specifying that it is *people* who reason and that their *manner of reasoning* is alike in these two domains, information implied but not directly stated in the source.

The French 'Ces deux sortes de Gens-là' (those two sorts of people) relies on the immediate preceding context to identify the groups being referred to. The English translation 'These two sorts of People, Lovers and Mathematicians,' explicitly names 'Lovers and Mathematicians,' making the reference direct and removing the reader's need for immediate inference.

The French 's'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche.' (if there is nothing otherwise that prevents me from it) uses the general 'rien' (nothing). The English 'if you have not some good reason to believe otherwise:' explicitates the nature of this potential impediment as 'some good reason,' specifying that the obstacle would be rational or evidential, a nuance implied but not spelled out in the source.

The French 'De là j'ay tiré que' (From that/thence I have deduced that) refers to the preceding principle of reasoning by analogy. The English translation 'Now this way of arguing have I made use of' explicitly identifies 'De là' not just as the origin point for the deduction, but as 'this way of arguing,' thereby naming the methodological step being taken.

The French 'tout ce qu'il a.' (all that it [the Sun] has) is a general statement. The English 'what is proper to that:' explicitates that 'all that it has' refers specifically to its characteristic attributes or essential properties, clarifying the nature of the comparison with fixed stars, which is implied in the scientific context but made more precise here.

The French 'sur le pied de cette ressemblance' (on the basis/footing of this resemblance) is an idiom. The English 'if you build upon this resemblance or likeness' makes the metaphorical idea of a 'basis' or 'footing' more explicit and active by using the verb 'build upon,' emphasizing that the resemblance serves as a foundational element for the argument.

The French 'sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur.' (its light must have infinitely more force on our eyes than theirs) describes a physical attribute ('force'). The English 'its Light makes a much greater impression on our Eyes, than theirs do:' explicitates the *perceptual effect* of this 'force,' clarifying how it manifests to the observer as an 'impression,' a consequence implied but not directly stated.

The French pronoun 'luy' (it), within the phrase 'Nous ne voyons donc que luy' (We therefore see only it), refers to the Sun. This is expanded in the target segment 'the light of our own Sun' (within 'We see nothing but the light of our own Sun'). The translator explicitly adds 'the light of' to specify that it is the Sun's luminosity being perceived, information which is contextually implied but not directly stated in the French.

The French 'il efface tout' (it effaces everything) is general. The translation 'it darkens and hinders us from seeing any other light' explicitates both *what* 'tout' (everything) refers to in this context (namely, 'any other light') and the *manner* in which the Sun 'effaces' these other lights ('darkens and hinders').

The French 'c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine' (it is another Sun that dominates there) uses the general verb 'dominer' (to dominate). The English translation 'there is another Sun, which rules and governs' expands on 'domine' by providing more specific verbs 'rules and governs,' thereby making the nature of the Sun's dominance within its vortex more explicit.

The French pronoun 'le nostre' (ours), within 'il efface à son tour le nostre' (it in turn effaces ours), refers to 'nostre Soleil' (our Sun). This is expanded in the target segment 'the light of our Sun' (within 'extinguisheth the light of our Sun'). The translator explicitly adds 'the light of' to specify that it is the Sun's luminosity that is extinguished, clarifying an aspect implied by the verb 'efface' (effaces/extinguishes) but not directly stated in relation to 'le nostre.'

The French 'grande voûte du Ciel' (great vault of the Sky/Heaven) uses 'voûte' (vault). The English 'great arched roof of Heaven' makes the implied shape more explicit by describing it as an 'arched roof,' providing a more concrete visual image than the more general term 'vault.'

The French 'Dans leur Monde' (In their World) is translated as 'In his own World or Sphere.' The addition of 'or Sphere' provides an alternative or clarifying term for 'Monde' (World) in the astronomical context of Cartesian vortices, explicitly suggesting the sun's domain or sphere of influence.

The French 'ils sont les uniques de leur espece' (they are the unique ones of their kind) states a characteristic. The English 'every Sun is single, and there is but one to be seen' explicitates the direct consequence or manifestation of this uniqueness in the context of observation: that each sun appears alone ('single') and is 'the only one to be seen' in its own system.

The French 'un fond de ressemblance' (a basis/foundation of resemblance), from the clause 'un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies', is rendered more specific in the English 'alike in one particular' (from 'tho' they may be alike in one particular, they may differ infinitely in others.'). The translator explicitates the nature of this 'fond' (foundation/basis) by clarifying that the resemblance is partial or specific to 'one particular,' which then logically sets up the contrast with differing in other aspects.

chunks.source_manual: <P092>Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que sçay-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour des Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil <UP></UP>, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vuide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extremitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vuide. Je ne doute pas mesme qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'estant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.</P092>
chunks.target_manual: <P072>It is certainly true, said I; but the difficulty is to know wherein they differ. One Vortex hath many Planets that turn round about its Sun; another Vortex hath but a few: In one Vortex, there are inferiour or less Planets, which turn about those that are greater; in another perhaps, there are no inferiour Planets; here, all the Planets are got round about their Sun, <UP>in form of a little Squadron</UP>; beyond which, is a great void space, which reacheth to the neighbouring Vortex's: In another place, the Planets take their course towards the out side of their Vortex, and leave the middle void. There may be Vortex's also quite void, without any Planets at all; others may have their Sun not exactly in their Centre; and that Sun may so move, as to carry its Planets along with it: others may have Planets which in regard of their Sun, ascend and descend, according to the change of their Equilibration, which keeps them suspended. But I think I have said enough for a Man that was never out of his own Vortex.</P072>
source_segments: dans l'autre il n'y en a point.
target_segments: to know wherein they differ
inferiour or less Planets
in another perhaps, there are no inferiour Planets;
in form of a little Squadron
without any Planets at all
But I think I have said enough
explanations: The French "de deviner" (to guess/to ascertain), in the phrase "la difficulté est de deviner" (the difficulty is to guess), refers to the challenge of discerning the unknown variations among different vortices. The English translation "to know wherein they differ" makes the object of this "guessing" more explicit by specifying that the difficulty lies in understanding *the specific ways in which* or *the particular aspects by which* the vortices are different, rather than just the general act of attempting to find out.

The French term "Planetes subalternes" (subordinate planets) is translated as "inferiour or less Planets." The addition of "or less" explicitly clarifies and potentially expands the meaning of "subalternes." While "inferiour" conveys a sense of lower rank or status, "or less" suggests that these planets might also be smaller in size or fewer in number, thus making the defining characteristics of this category of planets more explicit and accessible to the reader.

The French "dans l'autre il n'y en a point." (in the other there are none of them.) is part of a series of speculative statements. The English translation "in another perhaps, there are no inferiour Planets;" involves two explicitations:
1. The insertion of "perhaps" makes the hypothetical nature of this specific assertion explicit, reinforcing the overall speculative tone of the philosopher's discourse which is implied by the introductory phrase "Que sçay-je?" (What do I know?).
2. The anaphoric French pronoun "en" (of them), which implicitly refers to the previously mentioned "Planetes subalternes," is replaced by the explicit noun phrase "no inferiour Planets," thereby spelling out the connection and clarifying precisely what is understood to be absent in this other type of vortex.

The French phrase "font comme un petit peloton" (they form something like a small cluster/group, or small platoon) uses "peloton," a word with meanings ranging from a simple, somewhat undifferentiated cluster (like a ball of wool) to a small, organized military unit (platoon). The translation "in form of a little Squadron" makes a potential, less prominent implication of organized structure within "peloton" (particularly if understood in its military sense of "platoon") explicit by choosing "Squadron," a term that more strongly and specifically denotes an organized, often military, formation. This re-writes the image to be more defined and structured than the potentially more general French term.

The French phrase "sans Planetes" (without Planets) inherently implies a complete absence of planets. The English translation "without any Planets at all" makes this implicit idea of totality and completeness explicit through the addition of the intensifier "at all." This phrasing serves to emphasize more strongly the complete void or barrenness of such vortices.

The French "Enfin, que voudriez-vous?" (Finally, what more would you want/expect?) is a rhetorical question. In this context, it implies that the speaker believes he has provided a sufficient range of speculations and can offer no more, or that what has been said is adequate given the circumstances. The English translation "But I think I have said enough" makes this implicit conclusion or self-assessment explicit by stating it directly as a declarative sentence. This changes the rhetorical strategy by spelling out the intended meaning of the question.

chunks.source_manual: <P093>Ce n'en est guere, répondit-elle, pour la quantité des Mondes. Ce que vous dites ne suffit que pour cinq ou six, & j'en voy d'icy des milliers?</P093>
chunks.target_manual: <P073>It is not so much, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, considering what a multitude of Worlds there are; what you have said is sufficient but for five or six, and <UP>from hence I see thousands</UP>.</P073>
target_segments: the Countess
considering what a multitude of Worlds there are
explanations: The French source uses the pronoun "elle" (she), which refers to the Marquise (Fontenelle's interlocutor). The English translation replaces this pronoun with the specific title "the Countess" (the translator's consistent term for the Marquise). This substitution makes the speaker's identity more explicit within the sentence than the original pronoun, directly clarifying the referent rather than relying on pronominal reference to the established context.

The concise French prepositional phrase "pour la quantité des Mondes" (literally, "for the quantity of Worlds") is translated and expanded into the participial phrase "considering what a multitude of Worlds there are." This expansion is an instance of explicitation because it spells out the implied vastness of the worlds (using "multitude" and adding the existential clause "there are") and makes the logical connection ("considering") more prominent and explicit than the more condensed French original.

chunks.source_manual: <P094>Que serait-ce donc, repris-je, si je vous disois qu'il y a bien d'autres Etoiles Fixes, que celles que vous voyez; qu'avec des Lunettes on en découvre un nombre infiny qui ne se montrent point aux yeux, & que dans une seule Constellation, où l'on en comptoit peut-estre douze ou quinze <RW></RW>, il s'en trouve autant que l'on en voyoit <UP></UP> auparavant dans tout le Ciel?</P094>
chunks.target_manual: <P074>What, Madam, would you say, if I should tell you, there are many more fix'd Stars than those you see? and that an infinite number are discover'd with Glasses, which never shew'd themselves to our Eyes: In only one Constellation, where it may be, we count twelve or fifteen, there are as many to be found as usually appear in the whole Hemisphere.</P074>
source_segments: Que serait-ce donc, repris-je, si je vous disois
target_segments: What, Madam, would you say, if I should tell you
to our Eyes
in the whole Hemisphere
usually appear
explanations: The translator inserts 'Madam' as a vocative. The French phrase, beginning 'Que serait-ce donc, repris-je...', does not contain an explicit term of address at this point. Adding 'Madam' makes the specific addressee (the Marquise) explicit in the philosopher's speech, enhancing the dialogic directness.

The French 'aux yeux' (to the eyes) is rendered 'to our Eyes.' The addition of 'our' makes the implied human perspective explicit, specifying that the eyes are those of human observers rather than a general reference.

The French 'dans tout le Ciel' (in the whole sky) becomes 'in the whole Hemisphere.' The translator uses 'Hemisphere,' a more astronomically precise term for the visible portion of the sky from an observer's location on Earth, to make explicit an observational understanding implied by the general term 'Ciel.'

The French 'l'on en voyoit auparavant' (one saw them previously/before), referring to stars seen before telescopes, is translated as '[they] usually appear.' This makes explicit the implied habitual or typical nature of these pre-telescopic, naked-eye observations, shifting from a primarily temporal 'auparavant' (previously) to 'usually' which denotes frequency or commonness of visibility.

chunks.source_manual: <P095>Je vous demande grace, s'écria-t-elle, je me rends, vous m'accablez de Mondes & de Tourbillons. Je sçay bien, ajoûtay-je, ce que je vous garde ancore. Vous voyez cette blancheur qu'on appelle la Voye de Lait. Vous figureriez-vous bien ce que c'est? Une infinité de petites Etoiles invisibles aux yeux à cause de leur petitesse, & semées si prés les unes des autres qu'elles paroissent former une blancheur continuë. Je voudrois que vous vissiez avec des Lunettes cette Fourmilliere d'Astres, & cette graine de Mondes (si ces expressions sont permises.) Ils ressemblent en quelque sorte aux Isles Maldives, à ces douze mille petites Isles ou Bancs de Sable, separez seulement par des Canaux de Mer, que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez. Ainsi les petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait sont si serrez, qu'il me semble que d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler, ou mesme se donner la main. Du moins je croy que les Oyseaux d'un Monde passent aisément dans un autre, & que l'on y peut dresser des Pigeons à porter des Lettres comme on fait icy dans le Levant. Ces petits Mondes sortent apparemment de la regle generale, par laquelle un Soleil dans son Tourbillon efface dés qu'il paroist tous les Soleils étrangers. Si vous estes dans un des petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait, vostre Soleil n'est presque pas plus proche de vous, & par consequent n'a pas sensiblement plus de force sur vos yeux, que cent mille autres Soleils des Tourbillons voisins. Vous voyez donc vostre Ciel briller d'un nombre infiny de feux, qui sont fort proches les uns des autres, & peu éloignez de vous. Lors que vous perdez de veuë vostre Soleil particulier, il vous en reste encore assez, & vostre nuit n'est pas moins éclairée que le jour, du moins la diference ne peut pas estre sensible, & pour parler plus juste, vous n'avez jamais de nuit. Ils seroient bien étonnez, les Gens de ces Mondes-là, accoûtumez comme ils sont à une clarté perpetuelle, si on leur disoit qu'il y a des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits, qui tombent dans des tenebres tres-profondes, & qui quand ils joüissent de la lumiere, ne voyent mesme qu'un seul Soleil. Ils nous regarderoient comme des Estres disgraciez de la Nature, & fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition.</P095>
chunks.target_manual: <P075>I submit, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, and beg your pardon: You quite confound me with Worlds and Vortex's. I have yet more to tell you, Madam, said I: You see that whiteness in the Sky, which some call the milky way; Can you imagine what that is? 'Tis nothing but an infinity of small Stars, not to be seen by our Eyes, because they are so very little; and they are sown so thick, one by another, that they seem to be one cotinu'd whiteness: I wish you had a Glass, to see this Ant-hill of Stars, and this Cluster of Worlds, if I may so call 'em: They are in some sort, like the Maldivian Islands: those twelve thousand banks of Sand, separated by narrow Channels of the Sea, which a Man may leap as easily, as over a Ditch: So near together are the Vortex's of the Milky way, that the People in one World, may talk, and shake Hands with those of another; at least I believe, the Birds of one World, may easily fly into another; and that Pigeons may be train'd up to carry Letters, as they do in the Levant. These little Worlds are excepted out of that general Rule, by which one Sun in his own Vortex, as soon as he appears, effaceth the light of all other forreign Suns: If you were in one of these little Vortex's of the Milky way, your Sun would not be much nearer to you, and consequently, would not make any much greater sensible impression on your Eyes, than a hundred thousand other Suns of the neighbouring Vortex's: You would then see your Heaven shine bright with an infinite number of Fires, close to one another, and but a little distant from you; so that tho' you should lose the light of your own particular Sun, yet there would still remain visible Suns enough beside your own, to make your Night as light as Day, at least, the difference would hardly be perceiv'd, for the truth is, you would never have any Night at all: The Inhabitants of these Worlds accustom'd to perpetual Brightness, would be strangely astonish'd, if they should be told that there are a miserable sort of People, who where they live, have very dark Nights, and when 'tis Day with them, they never see more than one Sun; certainly they would think Nature had very little kindness for us, and would tremble with horrour, to think what a sad condition we are in.</P075>
